The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the 30th report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracey Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP
This committee is supported by staff of the Department of the House of Representatives

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament 3 July and 14 August 2024.
1. The committee resolved to present the following 2 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 7363 petitioners—requesting that independent local post offices be able to provide additional services to support communities (EN6326)
From 16046 petitioners—requesting that independent local post offices be able to provide additional services to support communities (PN0615)

span.span: 2. The following 55 ministerial responses to petitions were received.
Ministerial responses received by the Committee on 14 August 2024

PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following two petitions:
Australia Post

1. For our community to remain vibrant and relevant, it is essential that people can stay, live and work here, supported by essential infrastructure and services. 2. Our Post Office provides essential services to this community. It must therefore remain viable by being able to provide an increasing number of services to the communities, not less. 3. Our Community Post Office faces cuts in services and is unfairly blocked by Australia Post from providing other services. For the benefit of the whole community, our Community Post Office should be the local hub for ALL of my parcels, regardless of who sent my parcel to me or which delivery service they used. 4. Many Local Community Post Offices are independently-owned small businesses run by members of our community. It is essential that all businesses have an opportunity to grow. This can be achieved by increasing the number of services they provide and being able to choose how to serve their community better. 5. It will benefit our community if the Local Community Post Office is allowed to work with additional service providers, so they can provide more choice and more services to my community, allowing it to remain a viable business that can provide valuable services to our community for years to come.

We therefore ask the House to remove restrictions and allow the Licensees of Independent Local Post Offices to provide additional services and choice to better serve our local communities and remain sustainable for many years to come.
from 16,046 citizens (Petition No. PN0615)
Australia Post

1. For our community to remain vibrant and relevant, it is essential that people can stay, live and work here, supported by essential infrastructure and services. 2. For the benefit of the whole community, our Community Post Office should be the local hub for ALL of my parcels, regardless of who sent my parcel to me or which delivery service they used. 4. Many Local Community Post Offices are independently-owned small businesses run by members of our community. It is essential that all businesses have an opportunity to grow. This can be achieved by increasing the number of services they provide and being able to choose how to serve their community better. 5. It will benefit our community if the Local Community Post Office is allowed to work with additional service providers, so they can provide more choice and more services to my community, allowing it to remain a viable business that can provide valuable services to our community for years to come.

We therefore ask the House to remove restrictions and allow the Licensees of Independent Local Post Offices to provide additional services and choice to better serve our local communities and remain sustainable for many years to come.

Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 55 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented.
Superannuation
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4442 regarding borrowing within a self-managed superannuation fund.

Money borrowed by a self-managed superannuation fund under a limited recourse borrowing arrangement for the acquisition of an asset cannot be used to improve the value of the asset. As energy efficiency capital improvements are an improvement to the value of a rental property, this is not allowable under a limited recourse borrowing arrangement.

Borrowing within a superannuation fund inherently adds risk to the safety of retirement savings. Since superannuation receives substantial tax concessions designed to encourage people to save for retirement, it is important that there are safeguards in place to ensure that superannuation is preserved for its intended purpose of supporting income in retirement. Therefore, limited recourse borrowing arrangements applied for the acquisition of an asset cannot be used to improve the asset, as this could fundamentally change the nature of the asset used as security by the lender, potentially increasing the risk to the fund.

However, accumulated funds held by a self-managed superannuation fund can be used to finance capital improvements to assets acquired under a limited recourse borrowing arrangement, including energy efficiency improvements to rental properties. This is provided that the improvements do not fundamentally change the nature of the asset.

The Government considers that the current settings strike the right balance between allowing trustee(s) to maximise the returns in the superannuation funds and preserving superannuation for its purpose of providing retirement income.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Asylum Seekers
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 20 March 2023 to the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Andrew Giles MP, enclosing Petition EN4784, with 5506 signatures, concerning Australia's policy towards asylum seekers. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities I apologise for the delay in responding.

As you are aware, the Australian Government has provided a permanent visa pathway to existing Temporary Protection visa {TPV) and Safe Haven Enterprise visa (SHEV) holders. This permanent visa pathway has been made available through the permanent Resolution of Status (RoS) (subclass 851) visa.

Providing a permanent visa pathway to existing TPV and SHEV holders will empower them to move forward with their lives and to more fully contribute to Australia, gain secure employment, grow businesses, study more easily, sponsor eligible family members under the family stream of the Migration Program to Australia and pursue a pathway to Australian citizenship.

People granted a permanent RoS visa will be afforded the same rights and benefits as all permanent residents. Importantly, access to social security payments, the National Disability Insurance Scheme and some higher education assistance schemes will be available immediately, with no waiting periods.
The RoS pathway has been made available for those who held or applied for a TPV or SHEV before 14 February 2023.

Further information regarding the TPV/SHEV transition to RoS visas and fact sheets in different languages can be found on the Department of Home Affairs website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/resolution-of-status- 851#About.

The Government is committed to implementing this measure in an efficient and effective manner to ensure the majority of the caseload are granted a RoS visa within 12 months of processing commencement.

Persons who do not engage protection obligations, who are not awaiting a merits or judicial review outcome, and who have exhausted all avenues to remain in Australia, are expected to depart Australia voluntarily and may be provided assistance to depart.

The Government is committed to efficiently assessing each protection claim on its individual merits, on a case-by-case basis, with reference to up-to-date information on conditions in the applicant's home country. Principles of procedural fairness apply at all stages of visa decision making and most individuals have access to merits and judicial review of refusal decisions.

For applicants who have never held a TPV/SHEV, any TPV or SHEV applications remitted by the Immigration Assessment Authority (IAA), Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) or by the courts on or after 14 February 2023 will be assessed against the criteria for grant of a TPV/SHEV. If the applicant satisfies the criteria for the grant of a TPV/SHEV, the application will be converted to a RoS visa application.
The Government has announced reform to Australia's system of administrative review. This reform will abolish the AAT and replace it with a new federal administrative review body.

Please note that all cases currently before the AAT or IAA will continue. Many cases currently before the AAT/IAA will be decided or finalised before the new federal administrative review body is established. Any remaining cases will transition to the new review body.

The Government remains committed to delivering orderly and legal pathways to Australia through robust migration and humanitarian programs. As such, the Government has committed to maintaining Operation Sovereign Borders, including regional processing arrangements. Under this approach, anyone who attempts to travel to Australia by boat without a valid visa will be turned back to their point of departure, returned to their home country, or transferred to a regional processing country for assessment of their protection claims. The Government is also committed to finding durable migration outcomes for people under regional processing arrangements.

The Government of Nauru is responsible for the implementation of regional processing arrangements in Nauru, including the management of individuals under those arrangements. Australia supports Nauru to implement arrangements through the provision of contracted service providers.

Transitory persons in Nauru are not detained and are residing and working in the community. They have access to a variety of health and welfare services, including mental health services, delivered through the Regional Processing Centre Medical Centre and the Republic of Nauru Hospital. Clinical assessment and treatment is provided by a multi-disciplinary team of health practitioners, including general practitioners, nurses and counselling specialists. Specialist health services include psychology, psychiatry, dentistry, obstetrics, radiography and pharmacy services. Where clinically indicated specialist medical treatment is not available in Nauru, mechanisms are in place for temporary transfer to a third country for assessment and treatment.

The former Government ended Australia's regional processing association in Papua New Guinea (PNG) on 31 December 2021. PNG independently manages individuals remaining in PNG on a permanent or temporary pathway, including providing ongoing settlement support and services.

The Government is committed to finding durable migration outcomes for people under regional processing arrangements and continue to support the implementation of third country resettlement arrangements with the United States and New Zealand.

Over 1,000 people have already been resettled in the United States and several hundred have expressed interest in New Zealand resettlement. The Government is aware of transitory persons engaged in the Canadian Private Sponsorship of Refugees program, and is providing logistical assistance to Canada. Individuals are strongly encouraged to engage with available migration options. Third country resettlement provides the best available opportunity for individuals to achieve permanent migration outcomes and start the next phase of their lives.

Transitory persons brought to Australia from a regional processing country, such as for medical treatment, are here for a temporary purpose only. Transitory persons will not be settled in Australia and are expected to engage with third country migration options to depart Australia as soon as possible. Support and information is available for individuals to connect with existing migration options.

Individuals under regional processing arrangements have lived with uncertainty about their future since they arrived in 2013-14, and resettlement in a third country provides a permanent migration outcome not available here. Individuals are strongly encouraged to engage with available migration options. Third country resettlement provides the best available opportunity for individuals to build a path to a new life.

The Migration Act 1958 (the Act) creates a statutory framework regulating the entry and stay of non-citizens in Australia. Under the Act, non-citizens who do not hold a valid visa are liable for detention. However, immigration detention is used as a last resort and where possible, non-citizens are managed in the community pending resolution of their status.

The decision to place a person in held immigration detention is based on an assessment of risk to the Australian community. The length and conditions of immigration detention are subject to regular review by senior officers of the Department, as well as external independent review by the Commonwealth Ombudsman and the Australian Human Rights Commission.

Under the Act, detention is not limited by a set timeframe; rather, it ends when the person is either granted a visa or is removed from Australia. The Department always seeks to resolve the status of detainees in the shortest timeframe practicable; however, this is dependent upon a number of factors, including the level of cooperation of detainees towards immigration processes, or case complexity including in relation to health, character and/or security matters.

Australia is committed to its international obligations set out in the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol and other international human rights conventions to which it is a party. Australia does not return individuals to situations where they face persecution or a real risk of torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, arbitrary deprivation of life or the application of the death penalty.

Australia is, and will remain, a multicultural society of people drawn from a rich variety of cultural backgrounds. The Government knows the important social and economic contribution migrants and refugees have had through our nation's history.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4784 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neill
Taylor, Mr Julian Richard
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 22 May 2023 enclosing Petition EN4995, with 14 signatures, concerning the removal of Mr Julian Taylor from Australia. I apologise for the delayed response.

The Australian Government remains committed in its role of protecting the Australian community from risk of harm by non-citizens. It is expected that all non-citizens are law-abiding and continue to satisfy the requirements of the character test, as defined by section 501 of the Migration Act 1958 (the Act). Where individuals pose a risk to the community, the Australian Government will continue to cancel their visas and remove them.

On 21 December 2018, Mr Taylor's Class BB Subclass 155 Five Year Resident Return visa was cancelled under section 501(3A) of the Act on the basis of his substantial criminal record, having been sentenced to a full time term of imprisonment of 12 months or more. Between 22 October 2020 and 30 August 2022, Mr Taylor made a series of appeals in regards to his visa cancellation. Ultimately, on 8 December 2022, the High Court of Australia refused Mr Taylor's application for special leave.

Mr Taylor has reached the end of his appeal options in respect of his visa cancellation. On 6 January 2023, Mr Taylor was informed that he was on a removal pathway and that the department will make arrangements for his involuntary departure.
On 3 February 2023, Mr Taylor lodged section 195A and section 197AB onshore Ministerial Intervention applications.
On 2 March 2023, Mr Taylor was issued a Notice of Intention to Remove with an approximate removal date of 17 March 2023.
On 3 March 2023, Ministerial Direction 99 came into effect which made long-term residence in Australia a primary consideration in character-related visa decision¬ making.

Ministerial Direction 99 required decision-makers in both the Department of Home Affairs and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) to give greater consideration to the length of time a person has resided in Australia, when considering whether to refuse or cancel a visa under section 501 of the Act, and whether to revoke a mandatory cancellation decision, for all non-citizens.
This consideration needed to be balanced against other considerations including the seriousness of the conduct and expectations of the Australian community.

Ministerial Direction 99 could not be applied retrospectively. Non-citizens who have had their visa refused or cancelled under section 501 of the Act, or were subject to mandatory cancellation of a visa under section 501CA of the Act based on previous Ministerial Directions, or have had their case finalised, cannot have that decision changed.

It is important to note that Ministerial Direction 99 was a guide to character-related visa decision-making under section 499 of the Act. The Minister for Home Affairs and the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs cannot direct a delegate of the Minister to reach a particular outcome.
On 17 March 2023, Mr Taylor was found not to meet the section 195A and section 197AB guidelines for referral to the Minister.
Non-citizens who do not hold a valid visa will be liable for removal from Australia, pending resolution of any ongoing matters.

On 22 March 2023, Mr Taylor was involuntarily removed from Australia under section 198 of the Act. While Mr Taylor was removed involuntarily, he was provided with information about his removal about two and half months before his actual removal date, providing him opportunity to make arrangements regarding his belongings prior to his departure.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4995 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Medicare
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 1 August 2023 regarding Petition EN5135, requesting that gender affirming care not be covered under Medicare.

The Australian Government is committed to supporting all Australians to access high quality health care by providing Medicare benefits (rebate) for services listed on the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS), subsidised pharmaceuticals available through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and free hospital services for public patients in public hospitals.

Currently some surgical procedures that may be performed in the gender affirmation process attract a Medicare rebate. The Government relies on the judgement of health practitioners in determining the appropriate care for patients and upholding the principle of clinical relevance when deciding whether a procedure is necessary for a particular patient.

I can advise that the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC) has recently received an application for the public funding of patient consultations and surgical procedures for gender affirmation in adults with gender incongruence.

MSAC is an independent, expert advisory group which provides advice to the Government on whether a new medical service or technology should be publicly funded, based on an assessment of the comparative safety, clinical effectiveness, cost-effectiveness and total costs of services and/or procedures, using the best available evidence. The MSAC commonly assesses applications for new services seeking public funding on the MBS. Any person or organisation can submit an application to the MSAC for the consideration of public funding of a medical service.

The application will be considered following standard MSAC processes. The MSAC seeks feedback from relevant clinical and consumer organisations as part of the appraisal process for an application. Information about the MSAC consultation process can be found on the MSAC website at www.msac.gov.au/internet/msac/publishing.nsf/Content/MSAC-Consultation-Process.
The Government will consider the advice from MSAC on this issue when received. Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Parental Leave
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter of 11 September 2023 regarding petition EN5229 about fair and equitable access to parental leave. The Australian Government is committed to parental leave that supports families to balance work and care responsibilities. I acknowledge the concerns raised in the petition about the qualifying period to access parental leave entitlements.

Parental leave in Australia is facilitated by the government-funded Paid Parental Leave scheme and unpaid parental leave in the Fair Work Act 2009. Parental leave is an employee benefit received when an employee or an employee's partner gives birth (including adoption, surrogacy and stillbirth). The National Employment Standards in the Fair Work Act provide eligible employees an entitlement to 12 months of unpaid parental leave. Employees must have worked for their employer for at least 12 months before the date of birth or expected date of birth if the employee is pregnant, the date of adoption, or when the leave starts (if taken after another person who cares for the child takes parental leave).

The Government's current focus is expanding the Paid Parental Leave scheme that provides financial support to eligible working parents to support them to take time off work to care for their newborn or recently adopted child. The Paid Parental Leave scheme currently provides up to 20 weeks of payment, with 2 weeks reserved for each parent. Subject to the passage of legislation, the Paid Parental Leave Amendment (More Support for Working Families) Bill 2023 will expand payments under the Paid Parental Leave scheme to 26 weeks by 2026, with 4 weeks of the entitlement reserved for each parent.
Employers may provide paid parental leave in addition to the Government's Paid Parental Leave scheme, as well as unpaid parental leave policies above the minimum entitlement.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Mr Burke
Discrimination
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5240 for a proposed 'Mercy Amendment' to the Corporations Act 2001 (the Corporations Act). I appreciate the petitioners are very concerned about whistleblowing protections for victims of human rights breaches such as disability discrimination.

The whistleblower regime under the Corporations Act provides protection to whistleblowers against detriment related to the making of an eligible disclosure. Criminal offences and civil penalties may apply to companies or individuals that cause or threaten to cause detriment to a whistleblower or for breaching a whistleblower's confidentiality. Eligible whistleblowers include employees of a regulated entity and their spouse or relative. Regulated entities include companies and incorporated associations.
The private-sector whistleblowing regime sets out four key criteria that must be met for protection as a whistleblower:

1. The role of the whistleblower—people who can make disclosures include officers of a company or other regulated entity, employees, supplier, associate of the company or regulated entity, or their relatives. In all cases, the whistleblower holds the right to remain anonymous.

2. The company or organisation to which the disclosure relates—the regulated entities that the disclosure is about can include companies, bank (Authorised Deposit-taking Institutions), general or life insurers, or superannuation funds and trustees.

3. To whom the disclosure is made—disclosures must be made to certain recipients to be protected including a director, auditor (or member of an audit team), actuary, the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) or the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA).

4. The subject of the disclosure—whistleblowers must have reasonable grounds to suspect that the information they are disclosing about the company or regulated entity concerns misconduct or improper states of affairs or circumstances.

This information can be about the company or organisation, or an officer or employee of the company or organisation, engaging in conduct that breaches the Corporations Act or other financial sector laws, is an offence against any other law of the Commonwealth punishable by imprisonment for a period of 12 months or more, or represents a danger to the public or the financial system.

ASIC is Australia's corporate regulator. More information about whistleblower eligibility and protections, and information on how ASIC handles reports are available at: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/asic-investigations-and-enforcement/whistleblowing/.

The Government does not intend to make any changes regarding the 'Mercy Amendment' at this time. The whistleblower regime under the Corporations Act will soon be the subject of a statutory review which will provide an opportunity to consider these issues. The review must take place as soon as practicable after 1 July 2024. It will examine the effectiveness of the whistleblowing regime and whether any further changes should be made to protect and promote whistleblowing. As part of this review, interested parties will have the opportunity to submit their views.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5358 on requesting the RBA to disallow surcharging on non-cash transactions of all types.
The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) are responsible for regulating surcharging.

The RBA first introduced rules relating to surcharging in the early 2000s, allowing merchants to recover a reasonable cost of accepting relevant cards by imposing a surcharge. Today, a surcharge must only reflect the costs borne by the merchant to accept the card payment. The Government has banned excessive surcharging under the Competition and Consumer Amendment (Payment Surcharges) Act 2016.

The ACCC is responsible for enforcing the ban on excessive surcharging. More information for consumers is available at: https://www.accc.gov.au/consumers/prices-surcharges-receipts/credit-debit-prepaid-card- surcharges.

The RBA's Surcharging Standard requires banks to ensure merchants receive statements which clearly outline merchants' average cost of acceptance for each card scheme. This Standard is available at: www.rba.gov.au/payments-and-infrastructure/review-of-card-payments-regulation. The Standard is reviewed every three years and allows merchants to calculate their surcharge based on clearly documented cost information. The RBA also conducts a review of retail payments regulation every three years, with the next one due this year.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Australian War Memorials
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your representation of 4 June 2024 on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions regarding petitions EN5326, PN0599 and PN0598.

War memorials in all their forms across Australia are an important, and tangible way communities recognise this service and sacrifice of all those Australians who have served in wars, conflicts, and peace operations.

The Australian Government does not have jurisdiction over community, private or State and local council managed memorials. These memorials are usually erected by ex-service groups, veterans or their families and community members under arrangements with local Councils or State Governments. Their dedication, use and maintenance are managed under similar arrangements.

The Australian War Memorial' s Places of Pride initiative exists to record the location and photo of every publicly accessible war memorial in Australia. Community organisations, RSL sub-branches, local councils, schools, sporting groups and individuals are invited to contribute to this by sharing information and stories and uploading photographs. The initiative has over 11,700 memorials recorded. More information is available at placesofpride.awm.gov.au.

Listing a memorial on Places of Pride does not constitute a heritage listing. In order for a place to be heritage listed at the national level, it must have 'outstanding' heritage value to the nation. This means that it must be important to the Australian community as a whole. The majority of war memorials in Australia are unique to a local community or region. Heritage listing a memorial would be a matter for consideration at the State/Territory level, given the different eligibility requirements across jurisdictions.
The Australian Government can provide funding to assist the construction and restoration of war memorials, under DVA's Saluting Their Service (STS) Commemorative Grants Program.

The STS Program is an open-competitive program, which means that anyone can apply. Up to $3.5 million is available each year, with individual grants of up to $150,000 available. Further information is available on the GrantConnect website at www.grants.gov.au.
Yours faithfully,
from the Minister for Veterans Affairs, Mr Keogh
National Security
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 1 December 2023 to the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Andrew Giles MP, enclosing Petition EN5560, with 24 signatures, concerning ongoing protests in response to the Hamas-Israel conflict. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government recognises that there are many Australians deeply distressed by the ongoing Hamas-Israel conflict and continues to urge communities in Australia to remain respectful. While this distress is understandable, it is important that the Australian community remains cohesive and the Government strongly condemns anyone who incites violence and hatred within our community.
Australia has a long democratic history of recognition of the right to peaceful protest.

Our democracy also recognises this right is subject to general laws and must be balanced against the rights and interests of others and the community. While we respect the right for anyone in Australia to protest peacefully, violence will not be tolerated. The Australian Government has full confidence in state and territory police to manage any local protest activity. Individuals and communities planning a protest may be required to contact state or territory police, who can provide advice and assistance with safety, security matters and traffic controls.

The Australian Government will continue to act decisively to protect the community from the risk of harm posed by individuals who choose to engage in criminal activity or behaviour of concern, including visa cancellation where appropriate.

All non-citizens must meet, and continue to meet, the requirements set out in the Migration Act 1958 (the Migration Act) and the Migration Regulations 1994, including identity, security, health and character requirements.
If a person fails to comply with their visa conditions, engages in criminal activity or other behaviour of concern their visa may be considered for cancellation.
Further information regarding the character requirements is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-support/meeting-our- requirements/character.

The Migration Act provides the legal framework for the removal of unlawful non-citizens from Australia. This includes unlawful non-citizens whose visa has expired, whose visa has been cancelled or whose visa application has been refused. Under the Migration Act, a departmental officer has an obligation to remove an unlawful non-citizen who is liable for removal from Australia as soon as reasonably practicable.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5560 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neill
International Students
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to your correspondence of 26 February 2024 to the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Andrew Giles MP, enclosing Petition EN5768, with 4988 signatures, concerning the reduction of the maximum age from 50 to 35 years for the Temporary Graduate visa (TGV). Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I apologise for the delay in responding.

I acknowledge the concerns raised regarding recent announcements by myself and Minister Giles, on the age limitation adjustment for the TGV program outlined in the Migration Strategy. You will be pleased to hear that the Government has decided to retain the current age limit of 50 years of age for Masters by research and PHO graduates, due to their potential to contribute to Australia's economy and given they are typically older on average than other graduates.

For other graduates above the age of 35, a number of options remain for them upon completion of their studies, including temporary and permanent skilled visa products. These visas ensure graduates have skilled jobs and clear pathways to permanent residency and citizenship, which helps avoid many graduates from becoming 'permanently temporary'. Home Affairs will be facilitating a number of roundtables with education providers and employers over coming months that will outline many of these options for graduates.

Further information on these changes can be found on the Home Affairs website at https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/temporary-graduate-485/changes. Thank you for bringing Petition EN5768 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neill

Epilepsy
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding a petition for access to Health Care Cards (HCC) for individuals with epilepsy.
The Australian Government provides a range of support for people with severe medical conditions in recognition of the significant financial and emotional demands on individuals and families.

Under social security law, access to Government concession cards is determined based on financial need, rather than medical condition. Most Government concession cards are only available to recipients of social security payments, low-income earners, or certain self-funded retirees. The cards issued by the Government are the Pensioner Concession Card, the HCC and the Commonwealth Seniors Health Card.

Income and assets tests apply to most income support payments and are considered the fairest way to ensure the available funds are directed to those in the community with the greatest need, as determined by social security law.

The Low Income (LIHCC) is one of a small number of Government concession cards that can be issued to people who are not receiving a social security payment. The card is available to people with a low income, and is determined by their gross income, for the eight weeks immediately before they make a claim for the card.

Currently, the qualifying income limit for a single person with one dependent child is $1,315 per week. The LIHCC income limits are linked to the amount of income a single-income couple can earn before they stop being paid JobSeeker Payment. This is consistent with the low-income workers, who are the primary intended cohort for the card.

Once a person qualifies for the LIHCC, the relevant income limit can be exceeded by up to 25% before eligibility for the card is lost. For example, once qualified, a single person with one dependent child could earn up to $1,643 a week and still retain the card. This allows for some fluctuation in earnings for intermittent and part-time workers. The LIHCC is issued for an initial period of 52 weeks. After that, if a person still requires a card, they must again meet the qualifying income limits.
Where a person does not qualify for a concession card, the Government provides assistance with prescription and medical costs through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) and Medicare.

The 2023-24 Budget delivered landmark investments, including $6.1 billion in strengthening Medicare measures to revamp primary health care. This investment assists complex and chronic disease management, with improved support for bulk billing ($3.5 billion), longer consultations and multidisciplinary based care.

As part of the 2024-25 Budget, the Government announced that the indexation of PBS co¬ payment for people without a concession would be frozen for 12 months. Subject to legislation, the maximum co-payment will remain at $31.60 until 1 January 2026.

The PBS Safety Net provides assistance to those people who require a large number of PBS prescriptions over a calendar year. In 2024, once a person without a concession card has paid $1,647.90 in PBS co-payments, they pay for further PBS prescriptions at the concessional co-payment rate of $7.70 per prescription for the rest of the calendar year.

The Extended Medicare Safety Net provides additional Medicare benefits for families and singles who have out-of-pocket costs for Medicare eligible out-of-hospital services once an annual threshold has been met. In 2024, the annual threshold for people without a concession card is $2,544.30.

In addition to the above, the Epilepsy Foundation was awarded $20 million over a period of four years (2019-20 to 2022-23) for the implementation of the Epilepsy Smart Australia Program (ESAP). The ESAP is a comprehensive national program for epilepsy support and management, encompassing the establishment of the National Epilepsy Support Service. This service provides individualised support, education, and training.

In the 2024-2025 Budget, Epilepsy Action Australia received funding of$0.25 million for a one-year period. This funding aims to enhance the existing National Epilepsy Line and provide support to GPs in caring for patients with epilepsy.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler (Petition No EN5925)
Middle East
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your referring petition EN5932 to me, which relates to the Australian Victim of Terrorism Overseas Payment (AVTOP) scheme and a permanent ceasefire in the Hamas-Israel conflict.
I know the conflict in the Middle East is deeply distressing for many Australians, including the many Australians with a connection to the region and loved ones directly impacted.
The widespread human suffering we are witnessing in Gaza is completely unacceptable. This cannot continue. This war must end.

While Australia is not a central player, we have a respected voice and we are using it to advocate for a ceasefire, the protection of civilians, increased humanitarian assistance and the release of hostages.

We are using our voice and our vote in international institutions and forums. In December, Australia voted with 152countries for a ceasefire at the United Nations, and we support the ceasefire proposal endorsed by the UN Security Council in June this year. We want to see it fully implemented by both parties. Any delay will only see more lives lost.

I have pressed for a ceasefire, protection of civilians, humanitarian aid and the release of hostages through persistent and extensive engagement with foreign counterparts, including during my visit to the Middle East, as well as with partners in Europe, Canada, Japan, the UK, the US and in our region.

I have pressed the Netanyahu Government directly, as have Government officials in Canberra and in Israel. We continue to make clear Australia's objection to Israel's operation in Rafah and our expectation that Israel act in accordance with international humanitarian law. We have been clear with Israel that it must comply with the binding orders of the International Court of Justice, including to enable the provision of basic services and humanitarian assistance at scale. The Australian Government is denying anyone identified as an extremist settler a visa to travel to Australia.

We are pressing countries with influence over Hamas, to help secure the immediate and unconditional release of remaining hostages. We remain unequivocal in our condemnation of Hamas's horrific terror attacks of 7 October 2023.

We have adopted the most supportive position on recognition of any Australian government in history. We support recognition of a Palestinian state as a part of a peace process. And we are taking actions to make that possible. We want the legitimate aspirations of Palestinians to be realised—because a two-state solution is necessary for a just and enduring peace.

In May, Australia supported expanded Palestinian rights to participate in UN forums and the General Assembly's aspiration for eventual Palestinian membership of the United Nations, consistent with a two-state solution. Alongside key partners, we are looking at how we can support reform of the Palestinian Authority so that it can deliver on the needs of the Palestinian people.

On 2 February 2024, the Australian Government activated the AVTOP scheme to support all Australians impacted by the 7 October 2023 Hamas terrorist attacks. The AVTOP scheme provides financial assistance of up to $75,000 for Australian residents who are harmed, or whose close family member is killed, as a direct result of a declared overseas terrorist act. The AVTOP scheme acknowledges the collective responsibility of the Australian community to help individuals, and their families, recover from overseas terrorist acts.

This devastating crisis demonstrates the need for a political solution to the long running Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Australia remains steadfast in our support for a two-state solution—a Palestinian state and the State of Israel, living side by side in peace and security within internationally recognised borders.
I trust this information will be of assistance to the petitioners.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Veterans
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 14 May 2024 regarding Petition EN5935.

Petition EN5935 seeks amendment of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA) to reduce the timeframe provided in subsection 137(1) for the provision of information from the Secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs (OVA) to an applicant for a review by the Veterans' Review Board (the Board) from 'within six weeks' to seven days.

I note that it is the petitioners' belief that contemporary OVA electronic document storage practices means that the evidence can be instantly identified and retrieved, allowing Section 137 reports to be prepared and forwarded within a few hours or, at worst, a few days.

The phrase 'within six weeks' refers to the maximum timeframe in which the report under Section 137 is to be prepared by the Secretary and provided to the applicant who has made an application for review to the Board. This timeframe allows for a variety of administrative activities to be performed while factoring in the completion of competing work priorities. In some instances, documents relevant to the application for review may need to be retrieved from department archives. An appropriate timeframe is required to ensure the information is complete and accurate before it is provided to the applicant and subsequently to the Board to consider the application.

Furthermore, it has been a longstanding practice of the department to intervene before the report has to go to the Board where we may be able to make a new and beneficial decision in favour of the applicant. An appointed internal Review Officer will familiarise themselves with the facts of the case and review additional documents provided by the applicant to ensure that the decision was correct and in accordance with the legislation.

Under the proposed reform and harmonisation of veterans' legislation, subject to passage of the Veterans' Entitlements, Treatment and Support (Simplification and Harmonisation) Bill 2024 (the VETS Bill), future claims for compensation for all veterans, regardless of the time and nature of their service, would be covered under the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004 (MRCA). The Exposure Draft of the proposed changes to the MRCA legislation recommends a single review pathway.

Schedule 3, Part 1, Division 1, Section 10 of the VETS Bill seeks to amend the current legislation and introduce into the MRCA sections 352C and 352D. These would be applicable to Petition EN5935 as, if passed, they will mean that:
if an application for review is made to the Board, the Board must, as soon as practicable after receiving the application, give the Commission written notice of the application; and that

within 28 days after the Board notifies the Commission under section 352C of an application for review of an original determination, the Commission must cause a report to be prepared that refers to the evidence on which the original determination was based.

These changes would represent a reasonable reduction in the time. Frame for the Commission to provide the report to the applicant, with the aim of delivering quality decisions and sustainable outcomes.
Thank you for taking the time to bring this matter to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours faithfully,
from the Minister for Veterans Affairs, Mr Keogh
Cybercrime
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 May 2024 to the Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Clare O'Neil MP, regarding petition EN5939, create a national framework and revise current laws, in order to hold criminals accountable, and ensure that online platforms co-operate with law enforcement. As the issues raised fall within my p01ifolio responsibilities as the Attorney-General, your petition was referred to me for reply.
The Australian Government is committed to protecting the Australian community from increasingly sophisticated scams and combating the threat posed by cybercrime and
technology-facilitated abuse. The government has undertaken a range of actions to combat online harms and cybercrime, these include:

Introduction of the Criminal Code Amendment (Deepfake Sexual Material) Bill 2024 to the Australian Parliament on 5 June 2024 to amend the Criminal Code Act 1995 (Criminal Code) to modernise and strengthen offences targeting the creation and non¬ consensual sharing of sexually explicit material online, including material that has been created or altered using technology, such as deepfakes.

Committed to bringing forward legislation to outlaw the release of private information online (known as doxxing) and overhaul the Privacy Act 1988 to give all Australians, and particularly women who are experiencing domestic and family violence, greater control and transparency over their personal information.

Creating legislation to create a framework for mandatory industry codes that will outline the responsibilities of the private sector to address scam activity on their platforms and services. These measures will require businesses in key sectors to have measures in place to prevent, detect, disrupt, respond to and report scams. This will be complemented by strong regulator enforcement, penalties for noncompliance, and avenues for victim redress where wrongdoing by a regulated business occurs.

Conducting a comprehensive review, under Measure 13 of the National Strategy to Prevent and Respond to Child Sexual Abuse 2021-2030, of the Commonwealth child sexual abuse offences contained in the Criminal Code to ensure these offences remain current and reflect emerging trends in offending.

Releasing the 2023-2030 Australian Cyber Security Strategy in November 2023 setting out the government's roadmap and vision to improve national cyber security resilience and better support the Australian community in engaging online. This included investing $52.4 million over 5 years with an additional $11.1 million ongoing to enhance the cybercrime capabilities of the Australian Federal Police and its contribution to the joint standing operation with the Australian Signals Directorate, to investigate, target and disrupt cybercrime syndicates. (known as Operation Aquila).
Establishing the National Anti-Scam Centre partnering regulators, law enforcement and industry to detect, disrupt and prevent scams and fraud—https://www.accc.gov.au/national-anti-scam-centre.
Bringing forward the review of the Online Safety Act 2021 to ensure Australia's online safety laws remain fit-for-purpose and keep up with emerging online harms.

Bringing into force the landmark Australia-US Agreement on Access to Electronic Data for the Purpose of Countering Serious Crime which will transform and enhance international cooperation in addressing serious crimes, including terrorism and child sexual abuse, facilitated online. This includes allowing US and Australian authorities to obtain more timely access to electronic data held by service providers (such as Google, Meta and Microsoft) in the partner nation.

These actions are further supported by the government's robust criminal law offence framework established under the Criminal Code. It criminalises a range of criminal behaviour online including, online child sexual exploitation and abuse, harassment and computer crime.

The petition also makes particular reference to the rising use of online platforms to perpetrate family and domestic violence. The government is committed to ending violence against women and their children. All Australian Governments are working to deliver on the National Plan to End Violence against Women and Children 2022-2032 (National Plan). The National Plan includes technology-facilitated abuse as a key area of focus to address gender-based violence in Australia. The government has delivered a record $3.4 billion since October 2022 to support the National Plan.

Additionally, National Cabinet met on 1 May 2024 and agreed to a number of priorities to build on existing efforts under the National Plan. In response to this, the government will be introducing a suite of measures to help combat toxic views about women online. Other online safety measures to be led by the government include an age assurance technology trial and prioritising ongoing classification reforms to examine options to reduce exposure to violent pornography. The Government has also recently launched a new phase of the Stop it at the Start campaign, which includes a focus on countering violent and misogynistic content.

The government will continue to work to keep Australians safe online and hold those that commit technology-facilitated abuse and cybercrime (such online scams and fraud), accountable for their actions.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
E-Cigarettes and Vaping Products
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 May 2024 regarding petition number EN5940, requesting a revision of legislative changes affecting the regulation of e-cigarettes (vaping products) and related matters.

The Australian Government is taking clear action to reduce smoking and vaping rates through stronger legislation, enforcement, education, and support. This is because, despite Australia's success in reducing smoking rates over decades; tobacco continues to be the leading cause of preventable death and disability in Australia. There is evidence that non-smokers who vape are more likely to take up smoking, compared to those who do not vape. Normalisation of vaping has the potential to disrupt Australia's significant achievements in tobacco control.

Recent data shows that among people aged 14 years and over, current use of vaping goods nearly tripled between 2019 (2.5%) and 2022-2023 (7.0%). The increase was even more marked among young people, with current use of vaping goods increasing from 5.3% to 21% among people aged 18 to 24, and from 1.8% to 9.7% among people aged 14 to 17 during the same period. For more information you can visit the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare website at www.pp.aihw.gov.au and by searching the term 'Vaping and e-cigarette use in the NDSHS'.

The Therapeutic Goods and Other Legislation Amendment (Vaping Reforms) Act 2024 commenced on 1 July 2024. The Act forms a key piece of Australia's world-leading vaping reforms by prohibiting retailers such as tobacconists, vape shops and convenience stores from selling any type of vape. The Act also puts in place nationally consistent rules on the importation, domestic manufacture, supply, commercial possession and advertisement of all vapes.

These reforms protect young Australians and the broader community from the increasing health risks of vaping, while ensuring patients who legitimately need vapes to quit smoking or manage nicotine dependence can still access them. The Act builds on the Government's initial reforms to vaping products which commenced earlier in 2024, including a ban on the importation of disposable single-use vapes from 1 January 2024;

From 1 July 2024, all vapes, regardless of whether they contain nicotine or not, must be sold in a pharmacy. In addition, everyone will need a prescription from a doctor or nurse practitioner to buy vapes containing nicotine. Medical and nurse practitioners can prescribe therapeutic vapes for smoking cessation or the management of nicotine dependence.

This requirement for a prescription will be in place until 30 September 2024. More information is available at www.tga.gov.au and by searching the term 'Vapes: information for patients and consumers'.

Zero-nicotine substances and vapes will continue to be available to patients. The notified vapes list, which does include zero-nicotine products, will inform practitioners and pharmacists of vapes that can be lawfully prescribed or dispensed to patients. More information is available on the TGA's website by searching the term 'List of notified vapes'.

From 1 October 2024, further changes will come into place allowing patients aged 18 years and over to access vapes from a pharmacy without a prescription. These changes will help facilitate appropriate access to vapes for adults while maintaining appropriate controls and protections.

The Government continues to provide support for people who vape and/or smoke to quit and remain tobacco and vape free. Support is available from health professionals such as GPs, pharmacists, nurses, and specialists. Confidential advice is also available through the Quitline (13 78 48).Smoking cessation products that have been approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration following a rigorous assessment of their safety, quality, and efficacy also continue to be available, and some products are subsidised under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
The Government has also committed to several activities to increase vaping and smoking cessation support. These initiatives will build on existing measures and resources and include:

the creation of an online cessation hub at quit.org.au that contains information, tools, resources and a system to direct consumers to the best support mechanisms to assist them to quit smoking and vaping
the redevelopment of the My Quit Buddy app to provide both smoking and vaping cessation support
new clinical guidance, including for GPs, on smoking and vaping cessation
support for health professionals through continued funding of the National Quit Centre
improved access to Quitline and cessation support services across the country.

These initiatives complement other actions being taken by the Government in line with the National Tobacco Strategy 2023-2030 to reduce the rates of tobacco and e-cigarette use including stronger regulation of tobacco products under the Public Health (Tobacco and Other Products) Act 2023.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Telecommunications
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 14 May 2024 regarding Petition EN5943, which proposes a nationwide independent review of Telstra services.

I note the petition requests the House of Representatives conduct an independent nationwide review of Telstra services, specifically the effectiveness of these services in regional and remote Australia. The petition states the National Broadband Network (NBN) is not available in parts of regional and remote Australia.

The Australian Government recognises the importance of ensuring that all Australians have access to affordable, high-speed and reliable internet all across the country, especially in regional and remote areas. The NBN is the default platform for access to high speed broadband services across Australia. Access to fixed voice services is also currently provided by Telstra under the Universal Service Obligation. As set out further below, the Government has a number of measures in place, and is targeted investment focused on ensuring improved access to mobile and fixed telecommunications services in regional and remote Australia.

Further, an independent review into telecommunications services in regional, rural and remote parts of Australia must be undertaken every three years in line with the requirements of the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Act 1999.

The Regional Telecommunications Independent Review Committee for the 2024 review was announced on 25 January 2024 and the Committee is unde1iaking its work at present. More information on the review, including details on how to engage with the Committee is available at www.rtirc.gov.au.

The Government is investing $2.2 billion in improvements to regional connectivity. The Better Connectivity Plan for Regional and Rural Australia is providing more than $1.1 billion towards regional and remote communities to improve telecommunications services. The overall investment also includes upgrades to NBN services in regional areas.
The Plan provides $656 million in funding from the 2022-2023 Budget to improve place based and mobile services over five years. This includes:
funding focused on improving mobile coverage in under-served regional and remote communities with a focus on multi-carrier mobile coverage on regional roads
additional rounds of the Regional Connectivity Program to invest in placed-based digital connectivity infrastructure projects in regional communities
funding for on-farm connectivity solutions
funding for an independent audit of mobile coverage to better identify black spots
a funding boost for the Regional Tech Hub which supports regional consumers to access advice and support on digital connectivity options.
More detail on the different components of the plan can be found by visiting www.infrastrncture.gov.au/BCP

span.span: NBN Fixed Wireless and Satellite Upgrade Program

p.span: The Government has provided $480 million towards an upgrade of the NBN fixed wireless network by the end of 2024. This upgrade is also benefitting NBN satellite services.

NBN Co Limited (NBN Co) is using the latest 4G and 5G wireless technology to extend the coverage range from existing NBN fixed wireless towers, which is allowing higher speed services to everyone served by the towers. Under the upgrade, the fixed wireless footprint coverage will be expanded by up to 50 per cent, enabling 120,000 additional premises to access fixed wireless services instead of Sky Muster satellite services. Around three quarters of a million premises will be able to access fixed wireless services following the upgrades.

All premises in the new, expanded fixed wireless coverage footprint will be able to access higher peak speed services of 100 megabits per second (Mbps) download with peak upload speeds of up to 20 Mbps. Residents on plans with speeds of at least 50 Mbps will be able to attain typical wholesale speeds of at least 50 Mbps download during the busy hours. Those residents that have chosen lower speed plans will also experience a better quality of service over fixed wireless as a result of the upgrades.

As the upgrade rollout has progressed, NBN Co has found the network is capable of delivering even better speeds above and beyond the original commitments. New speed tiers have now been delivered under the upgrade that offer speeds close to double those originally planned, with 80 per cent of fixed wireless premises nationally expected to be able to access download speeds of up to 400 Mbps and upload speeds of 10-40 Mbps by the end of 2024.

For sate1lite users, the movement of premises off the NBN Sky Muster sate1lites is relieving satellite capacity, allowing NBN Co to enhance its satellite products. The upgrades will also generally enhance NBN Sky Muster satellite service performance.

The upgrade has enabled NBN Co to launch a new product, Sky Muster Plus Premium, which is fully unmetered, the first Sky Muster product to have such a feature. This product can offer speeds of up to 100 Mbps.
NBNCo is currently rolling out access to higher wholesale speeds and greater capability to homes and businesses on its fixed-line network by 2025.

As part of this investment, NBN Co is extending fibre deeper into many fibre to the node (FTTN) areas to provide the option of higher speeds as customer demand emerges over the next few years. Eligible premises connected to the NBN, via FTTN technology, that require higher speeds will be able to access higher wholesale speed tiers via fibre to the premises (FTTP) technology. This will be done by using existing fibre infrastructure already built to nodes and investing in the continued rollout of fibre deeper into neighbourhoods.

NBN Co's fibre upgrade program has been boosted by the Government's $2.4 billion equity investment to expand full-fibre access to 1.5 million additional premises by the end of 2025. Importantly, this investment will provide full-fibre access to an additional 660,000 premises in regional areas.
As a result of the Government's investment, 90 per cent of homes in the fixed-line footprint will have access to gigabit speeds by late 2025.

In October 2023, I announced a review of universal service arrangements. The review aims to consider and modernise these arrangements in light of changes in available technologies and consumer preferences over recent years. This work is currently underway and has involved public consultation on both delivery and funding of services. More detail is available from www.infrastructure.gov.au/media-communications-arts/modernising-universal¬ telecommunications-services
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Veterans
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 May 2024 regarding petition EN5961 seeking changes to the Statements of Principles (SoPs) issued by Repatriation Medical Authority (RMA) for use in the determination of certain compensation claims by Australian veterans in respect of Tooth Wear.

I understand that the petitioners seek to have a clause added to the SoPs for Tooth Wear to the effect that these SoPs exclude the condition of minor tooth wear, and that claims for this condition can be considered by the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) as 'non-SoP' conditions.

Section 6(2)(e) of the SoPs for Tooth Wear already state that they do not apply to minor tooth wear that is confined to the enamel. The Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA) separately defines the process to be taken to assess a condition for which there is no applicable SoP. In such cases, it is necessary to consider whether it constitutes an injury or disease and the decision-maker must determine the claim based on the totality of the available evidence.

SoPs are determined by the RMA, which is an independent expert body. The RMA has a specific role set out in section 196B of the VEA, which is limited to determining SoPs, or making decisions not to produce SoPs, on the basis of sound medical-scientific evidence.

Neither the Parliament, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, nor DVA have the power to direct the RMA to include or exclude provisions in the individual SoPs which it produces. The provisions of the VEA are specifically designed to safeguard the RMA's ability to carry out its functions independently.

Consequently, it is not possible to take the actions requested by the petitioners requiring the RMA to include within the SoPs information about lodging claims for minor tooth wear, nor, as noted above, is such change necessary given the provisions within the relevant SOP and the VEA.

However it is important to note that the Albanese Labor Government is simplifying and harmonising Australia's veterans' rehabilitation and compensation system -with new legislation introduced into the Parliament on 3 July 2024. Under the Veterans' Entitlements, Treatment and Support (Simplification and Harmonisation) Bill 2024 (the Bill), all new compensation claims from 1 July 2026 will be dealt with under a single piece of legislation—an improved Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004 (MRCA)—regardless of when or where the veteran served.
This is another important step in our Government's response to the Royal Commission into Defence and Veteran Suicide's Interim Report and is the result of significant community consultation.

I acknowledge that not everyone will share the same opinion about the Government's decisions or policy approaches. However I consider it important that everyone has an opportunity to have their say about the issues that matter to them.
Thank you, and the petitioners, for taking the time to bring this matter to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours faithfully,
from the Minister for Veterans Affairs, Mr Keogh
Motor Neurone Disease
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 30 May 2024 regarding the two petitions, reference numbers PN0603 and EN5968, presented in the House of Representatives relating to making Motor Neurone Disease (MND) notifiable. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The National Notifiable Disease List (NNDL) is a legislative instrument under the National Health Security Act 2007. The Australian Government Minister for Health may vary the NNDL (add or delete a disease) following consultation with the Commonwealth Chief Medical Officer and each state and territory Health Minister. Temporary additions may also be made by the Minister without consultation, but are only considered for public health emergencies, most recently COVID-19 and Mpox.

For status as a nationally notifiable disease to have any practical effect, the disease must be notifiable in the states and territories, as this will provide the basis for laboratories and state and territories to collect the information under jurisdictional public health legislation. At this stage MND is not notifiable in any state or territory. The critical points to note are that:

Communicable Diseases Network Australia (CDNA) jurisdictional representatives need to agree unanimously that an assessment panel is required and even if the assessment panel recommend listing, they also need to unanimously support listing for it to progress further;
the panel criteria are skewed towards communicable diseases with distinct public health action as that is the focus of the NNDL; and
the timeframe for listing permanently is approximately 12 months and each new listing typically starts from 1 January to ensure a full year of data are collected.

Conditions listed on the NNDL are also notified by the states and territories through to the National Notifiable Disease Surveillance System (NNDSS). The NNDSS is a de-identified database designed to capture only acute data for the purposes of public health response (e.g. COVID-19, salmonellosis, syphilis etc). Listing would indeed ensure all cases nationally are notified, but the exposure data captured is limited and it cannot store the sort of longitudinal data that would be required for a MND Register.

If you would like to nominate MND for assessment, please write to the Commonwealth CDNA representative Ms Emma Denehy at the email address Emma.Denehy@health.gov.au outlining your reasons for nominating MND, and how these reasons are informed by the NNDL criteria, and this nomination will progress through to the CDNA for consideration.

The Government has allocated $550,000 to the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare to report on neurological conditions more comprehensively. This funding will be used to create a specialized dashboard for monitoring the prevalence and impact of several conditions, including MND, and to establish a system for updating data regularly.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Nuclear Energy
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 May 2024 regarding petition EN5972 on the implementation of nuclear power in Australia. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government has no plans to change the longstanding moratorium on nuclear power in Australia, which is prohibited by law under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.

In countries with established nuclear power industries, nuclear power can provide a low emissions alternative to fossil fuels. In the context of our own clean energy transformation, the high cost and long deployment time of nuclear power makes it an unviable choice for Australia.

The GenCost 2023-24 report, prepared by the CSIRO and the Australian Energy Market Operator (AEMO), shows that renewables remain the cheapest form of generation for Australia, even when additional costs for storage and new transmission are included. Renewable technologies are quicker to build and cheaper to operate.

Putting downwards pressure on electricity prices is why we are focused on transforming our electricity system so that more renewable energy powers our homes. Under the Government's Powering Australia plan, we are investing $20 billion to upgrade Australia's electricity grid, and delivering an expanded Capacity Investment Scheme to deliver 32 GW of renewable capacity by 2030. We are also investing $100 million in solar banks and $200 million in new community batteries to help more people access solar and maximise the benefits of Australia's energy transformation.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen

subdebateinfo.title: Freedom of Religious and Spiritual Practice

p.span: Freedom of Religious and Spiritual Practice
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 14 May 2024 regarding Petition EN5983 about the operation of the Shincheonji Church in Australia.

Australia is home to a diversity of faiths and all Australians are free to choose their religion, and are entitled to express and practice their religion and their beliefs, without intimidation and without interference, as long as those practices are within the framework of Australian law.

While I understand the concerns raised in the Petition, section 116 of the Australian Constitution prevents the Commonwealth from passing laws establishing any religion, imposing any religious observance or prohibiting the free exercise of religion.

Should the actions of the church breach any criminal laws, investigation of any alleged crime is generally a matter for policing authorities. If there are concerns about alleged criminal activity, evidence should be provided to local state or territory police. Police operate independently of government and the decision whether or not to investigate an alleged offence is a matter for their determination.

The Government believes that no Australian should be discriminated against because of who they are or what they believe and will continue to seek to enhance protections in anti-discrimination law in a way that brings Australians together.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
National Security
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 May 2024 and for enclosing Petition EN5996, with 63 signatures, concerning the issue of political interference mentioned in the 2024 Director-General of Security's (Director-General) Annual Threat Assessment.

The Director-General confirmed on 29 February 2024, that it is the longstanding practice of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation to not publicly discuss individuals or to provide operational details. The Director-General outlined multiple reasons for this, including the need to protect sources and capabilities. The Director-General has also confirmed that the individual is no longer a security concern and that the matter was appropriately dealt with at the time.

Espionage and foreign interference is now Australia's principal security concern. The intent of the Director-General's 2024 Annual Threat Assessment is to raise awareness of these threats, including attempts to interfere in our democratic processes. It is important Australians know how to recognise these threats to ensure they can resist and report them.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5996 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neill
Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 14 May 2024 regarding petition number EN6020, about increasing production of lisdexamfetamine (Vyvanse).
I appreciate that the petitioners are very concerned about availability of Vyvanse and that many Australians have been affected by recent shortages of this medicine.

I assure you that managing medicine supply is a priority for the Australian Government. The Government recognises the importance of a reliable supply of essential medicines, including Vyvanse, and continuously works with pharmaceutical companies (known as sponsors) to help facilitate supply and minimise the effects of shortages on patients.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration {TGA), which is part of the Department of Health and Aged Care, actively monitors the supply of medicines in Australia. While it is not responsible for coordinating the actual supply of medicine, the TGA gathers information about anticipated and current medicine shortages and discontinuations. It undertakes a range of activities to anticipate, monitor and resolve supply disruptions and communicate timely information to affected stakeholders, including patients and health professionals.

Actions the TGA can undertake to reduce the impact of medicine shortages include approving the supply of suitable overseas-registered alternative medicines (which it did to help increase supply during this shortage), and working with sponsors to minimise regulatory barriers that may delay the supply of medicines. However, it is important to understand that the Government cannot compel a sponsor to register, market or manufacture a medicine in Australia, or to direct supply from other markets to Australia.

Importantly, medicine shortages are not unique to Australia. They occur for many reasons and sometimes cannot be avoided. In the case of Vyvanse, the sponsor, Takeda Pharmaceuticals Australia (Takeda), advised the TGA that the shortages were due to manufacturing issues, and that the limits imposed by the United States Drug Enforcement Agency on lisdexamfetamine supply referred to in the petition were not the cause.

Takeda notified the TGA at the end of April 2024 that shortages of all strengths were resolved. However, Vyvanse 20 mg capsules have since returned to shortage (expected to be resolved on 21 August 2024), while the 60 mg capsules are expected to be in shortage between 30 August and 21 October 2024.

Resolution of a shortage means that the sponsor has sufficient stock of their medicine to meet the usual national demand and is available to be released to wholesalers. However, during these shortages, many people were prescribed alternative strengths. The increased demand for different strengths may cause some further supply disruptions, which may continue for some time until people are able to return to their original prescription. The TGA is continuing to work with Takeda and wholesalers to help facilitate efficient and equitable distribution of stock across Australia.
Up-to-date and detailed information about the shortages of Vyvanse is available on the TGA website at www.tga.gov.au/vyvanse-shortage.

Petitioners also specifically requested regulatory reforms to remove barriers for generic alternatives to Vyvanse, and for the Government to place similar medicines on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).

Regarding generic alternatives, the TGA registered a generic brand of lisdexamfetamine (Actavanz) in January 2024. However, it is not currently supplied, as Takeda holds the patent for the manufacture and supply of lisdexamfetamine in Australia and it does not expire until July 2028. The Australian patent differs from the patent in the United States, which expired in August 2023. Currently patents are required to be registered separately in each country arid they are subject to the individual conditions of that country. Generic market entry often coincides with the expiry of the compound patent. Generic companies may seek to enter the market sooner by challenging the validity of patents covering the relevant product in court.

Regarding PBS subsidy, I appreciate concerns about the high cost of the overseas-registered alternative products (those approved for temporary supply under section 19A of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989). To list a medicine on the PBS (including a medicine supplied under section 19A), the sponsor needs to submit a formal request to the Government. This request is then considered by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC), which is an independent expert body that advises the Government about the listing of medicines on the PBS. The Government cannot list a medicine on the PBS unless the PBAC makes a recommendation in favour of it. Importantly, sponsors make their own decisions about whether or not to apply for PBS listing and the Government cannot compel them to do so.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Mental Health
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 May 2024 regarding petition number EN6029 requesting to provide the Karratha/Pilbara region with an inpatient/outpatient mental health facility. The petition also requested adequate psychiatric professionals be based residentially for consistent ongoing care for both youth and adults experiencing mental-ill health.

I am sorry to learn of the loss of Mr Machlan Felix.
