The Australian Government recognises the impact that suicide has on individuals, families and communities and is committed to developing a more effective mental health system that prevents suicide and improves the lives of all Australians with or at risk of mental illness.

Specialist services for people experiencing acute mental ill-health are generally funded and delivered by state and territory governments. The Western Australian (WA) Government is responsible for public hospital systems, including planning and delivering clinically necessary inpatient and outpatient services. I understand that Mr Felix's family has also started a petition urgently calling for the WA Government to establish a residential mental health facility in Karratha for those in acute need and that this was tabled in state parliament in April 2024.

The Government also recognises that the mental health workforce is critical to the delivery of high-quality mental health services. Under the National Mental Health and Suicide Prevention Agreement (National Agreement), all governments have agreed to work together to build a mental health and suicide prevention workforce that is culturally safe and responsive to changing needs. The National Agreement also includes a commitment for all governments to implement the National Mental Health Workforce Strategy 2022-2032 (Strategy).

The Strategy provides a roadmap to build a sustainable workforce that is skilled, well- distributed and supported to deliver mental health treatment, care and support that meets current and future needs. The Government is working with all state and territory governments, alongside First Nations and Lived Experience representatives, to guide implementation of the Strategy through the National Mental Health Workforce Working Group (Working Group).

Ensuring Australians can access high-quality mental health care is a priority for the Government and the 2023-24 Budget provided $109.1 million to increase the availability and capability of our mental health workforce. This investment addresses critical shortages in the psychology workforce by providing additional postgraduate psychology places, internships and supervisor training places, and upskills the broader health workforce in mental health to alleviate system pressure. These measures will help address critical workforce shortages and prevent gaps in services from widening while the Government pursues long-term solutions to structural issues within the mental health system across different professions and programs.

The Government is also committed to addressing the challenges faced by the psychiatry profession, including acute workforce shortages. It is recognised that these shortages have an impact on access to care and services. There are a number of investments in place to support the growth of the psychiatry workforce across a range of settings. The Government is investing an additional $40.5 million over four years (2021-22 to 2025-26) to increase the psychiatry workforce through the Psychiatry Workforce Program (PWP). A key objective of the PWP is to increase the psychiatry workforce in rural and remote areas across Australia. This includes funding to support up to 30 Full-Time Equivalent training posts per year and development of a Certificate of Psychiatry to broaden the skillsets of GPs and other medical practitioners to confidently deliver higher levels of mental health care in a range of health settings.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the AssistantMinister for Mental Health and Suicide Prevention, Ms McBride
Animal Welfare
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 14 May 2024 regarding the petition to allow for a myxomatosis vaccine to be used in pet rabbits in Australia (Petition EN6031).
I note that pet rabbits are much loved members of many Australian families, and with no effective treatment for myxomatosis, I understand the distress that this disease causes rabbit owners.

Unfortunately, there are no vaccines registered for use in Australia for protecting pet rabbits against myxomatosis. The myxomatosis vaccines that have been available overseas are live attenuated vaccines (also known as 'modified live' vaccines). As the virus in these types of vaccines maintains its infectivity to stimulate an immune response, there is a potential risk that the vaccine virus may spread from vaccinated pet rabbits into the wild rabbit population. The live vaccine virus could be transmitted between rabbit populations, increasing the immunity of wild rabbits to myxomatosis, and leading to an increase in their population numbers.

Wild rabbits are one of Australia's most serious feral pest animals. They have been implicated in broad scale land degradation, the near-extinction or extinction of small native mammals and plants and are a food source that maintains populations of other introduced pests. However, feral animal control is complex and many factors—including technical, environmental, social and animal welfare issues—must be considered when developing appropriate policies and solutions. Biological control agents are a necessary option for controlling some feral animal species so that native biodiversity can be protected. In the case of wild rabbits, the myxoma virus remains an important measure in keeping their numbers under control.

Work previously undertaken by the Centre for Invasive Species Solutions and CSIRO identified alternative myxomatosis vaccines that may be suitable for use in Australia, however, these vaccines have not been developed beyond the experimental stage. If a vaccine was successfully developed, the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority would require the vaccine manufacturer to apply to register the product for use in Australia. It is up to vaccine manufacturers to decide whether it is commercially viable for them to engage in the registration process.

I realise that this is disappointing for pet rabbit owners, but I hope that they can understand that for now, protecting domestic rabbits from myxomatosis in Australia must be done by means other than vaccination. I encourage them to seek veterinary advice on how to protect their pet rabbit from this disease, in particular protection from mosquitos and fleas as these insects transmit the myxoma virus.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Mr Watt
National Security
Dear Chair

Thank you for providing me the petition presented to the House of Representatives regarding the Joint Defence Facility Pine Gap and other joint and collaborative facilities in Australia. I appreciate the concerns raised by Mr Drew Armstrong on this matter.

Australia's strategic circumstances are the most complex and challenging they have been since the end of the Second World War. Australia's Alliance with the United States is fundamental to our national security and the Australian Defence Force's ability to generate, sustain and project credible military capability.

Our cooperation with international partners, including the United States, is managed through robust policy frameworks and principles that maintain and protect our sovereignty. These frameworks govern the activities of foreign governments in, from or through Australia. They also guide how we partner together to conduct activities and acquire capabilities in line with Australia's national interests.

The Australian Government carefully manages all foreign defence force access, posture and training on Australian territory by ensuring all such activities align with Australia's national interests and preserve Australia's sovereign decision-making. These decisions are not dictated by the interests of other nations—rather they are mutually agreed activities in the interests of both countries.

These activities only occur at the invitation of the Australian Government with full respect for our sovereignty, and domestic and international laws. A fundamental principle underpinning these activities is the longstanding bipartisan policy of having no foreign bases on Australian sovereign territory.

Australia's cooperation with the United States through joint and collaborative facilities, including Joint Defence Facility Pine Gap, is one of our most longstanding security arrangements. These facilities provide critical functions that directly support our national security, which we would not be able to realise by ourselves.

A fundamental element of our cooperation with the United States at these joint and collaborative facilities is our longstanding and bipartisan policy of full knowledge and concurrence, as articulated by the Hawke Government. 'Full knowledge' means Australia has a full and detailed understanding of any capability or activity with a presence on Australian territory, or making use of Australian assets. 'Concurrence' means that Australia approves of the presence of a capability or function in Australia, in support of mutually-agreed goals.

These principles protect Australia's right to know, understand and agree to foreign government military and intelligence activities conducted in, from or through Australia and through the use of our assets. The mechanisms by which we achieve full knowledge and concurrence at these facilities are pragmatic—such as data sharing, and joint operations and activities. Our full knowledge and concurrence framework also evolves to ensure the activities align with our national interests and the maintenance of our sovereignty.

Given their continued contribution to the security of Australia and our region, there are no plans to close joint and collaborative facilities in Australia, including Joint Defence Facility Pine Gap. As articulated in my February 2023 Statement to Parliament on Securing Australia's Sovereignty, I am assured that the Australian Government maintains appropriate levels of oversight for the activities undertaken at these facilities and that those activities are in Australia's national interests.
Thank you for bringing Mr Armstrong's petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles
Personal Information and Privacy
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 May 2024 to the Minister for Industry and Science, the Hon Ed Husic MP, regarding petition EN6055 to introduce laws to protect the public from current and emerging communication technologies and remote neuromonitoring. As privacy issues fall within my po1tfolio responsibilities as the Attorney-General, your email was refe1Ted to me for reply.

The Privacy Act 1988 (Privacy Act) regulates the collection, use, disclosure and storage of individuals' personal information. The Privacy Act contains 13 Australian Privacy Principles (APPs) which apply to 'APP entities', including Australian Government agencies and private sector organisations with an annual turnover of more than $3 million. Neurotechnology often involves the collection of sensitive personal information, which has a higher level of protection under the Privacy Act than other personal information. The Attorney-General's Department commenced a comprehensive review of the Privacy Act in October 2020 and the Government released the Privacy Act Review Rep01t in February 2023.

The Privacy Act Review considered the privacy landscape in Australia, and identified a number of risks and opp01tunities associated with the widespread adoption of new technologies. Feedback to the Review made it clear that the Privacy Act has not kept pace with technological advancements and that reform is needed. On 28 September 2023 the Government released its response to the Privacy Act Review Report, which agreed or agreed in-principle to progress 106 proposals for reform. The Government is committed to ensuring the Privacy Act is fit-for¬ purpose in the digital age and protects individuals from harmful practices.

The Government response to the Privacy Act Review Rep01t agreed that individuals should have greater transparency and control over their personal information. In particular, the Government agreed in-principle that entities should be required to ensure all collections, uses and disclosures of personal information are fair and reasonable in the circumstances. Introducing a 'fair and reasonable' test will help protect individuals from unexpected and harmful information-handling practices. This requirement would apply even if an individual had consented to their personal information being collected, use or disclosed for a particular purpose, to protect individuals from being nudged towards consenting to more privacy intrusive practices or selecting more privacy intrusive settings.
There is a clear need for privacy reform, and the Government is committed to updating the Privacy Act for all Australians.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
International Relations: Australia and Israel
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email of 3 June 2024, regarding petition number EN6075 on Australia's support to Israel.

The Australian Government does not provide financial or military aid to Israel, either directly or indirectly via other countries. Australia has also not supplied weapons or ammunition to Israel since the conflict began and for at least the past five years.
I know the conflict in the Middle East is deeply distressing for many Australians, including the many Australians with a connection to the region and loved ones directly impacted.
The widespread human suffering we are witnessing in Gaza is completely unacceptable. This cannot continue. This war must end.

While Australia is not a central player, we have a respected voice and we are using it to advocate for a ceasefire, the protection of civilians, increased humanitarian assistance and the release of hostages.

Australia continues to support the international community's response to the humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza. Since October, Australia has committed $72.5 million to address urgent needs arising from the conflict in Gaza and the protracted refugee crisis in the region. This includes our commitment in June this year of an additional $10 million through the World Food Programme to provide life-saving food assistance to civilians in Gaza at risk of famine.
This devastating crisis demonstrates the need for a political solution to the long running Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
Australia remains steadfast in our support for a two-state solution—a Palestinian state and the State of Israel, living side by side in peace and security within internationally recognised borders.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Consumer Protection: Digital Products
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN6080, requesting legislation to ensure software sold in Australia remains in a functional state after the end of the product's support period. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

In Australia, businesses are generally free to set the terms and conditions for the products they sell. For digital products such as video games, consumers often purchase a licence to use the product and do not have direct ownership over that product. This means that consumers' rights in relation to digital products are primarily governed by the terms and conditions set by the businesses in the associated licencing agreement.

Terms and conditions in licencing agreements are subject to the statutory protections in the Australian Consumer Law (ACL). Under the ACL businesses are prohibited from engaging in unconscionable, misleading or deceptive conduct. The ACL also prohibits businesses from making false or misleading representations about the goods or services they sell, and from including unfair terms in their licencing agreements where these are standard form contracts. A standard form contract is prepared by one party to a contract with the other party having little or no opportunity to negotiate terms. Terms are unfair if they:
cause a significant imbalance in the rights and obligations of the parties under the contract,
are not reasonably necessary to protect the legitimate interests of the party who gets an advantage from the term, and
would cause financial or other harm to the other party if enforced.

In October 2022, the Government passed legislation through the More Competition, Better Prices Bill to strengthen unfair contract terms protections. The amendments came into effect on 9 November 2023 and introduced a civil penalty regime prohibiting the use of and reliance on unfair contract terms in standard form contracts.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) provides further information about unfair contract terms on its website, available at: www.accc.gov.au/business/selling-products-and- services/contracts#toc-unfair-contract-terms.

The ACL also creates a basic set of guarantees for consumers who purchase goods or services, including digital products such as video games. These are intended to ensure consumers receive the goods or services they have paid for. When one or more of these guarantees has not been met, the consumer is entitled to a remedy. The type of remedy depends on the circumstances but may include a repair, replacement or refund.

The Government is currently considering options to improve the effectiveness of the consumer guarantee provisions of the ACL. These include consideration of penalties and enforcement mechanisms to ensure businesses comply with their obligations.

The ACCC has published guidance about consumer guarantees. This provides information on how consumers can protect their rights when buying goods or services, including digital products, and is available at: https://www.accc.gov.au/consumers/buying-products-and-services/consumer-rights-and-guarantees.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Personal Information and Privacy
Dear Chair
In response to petition number EN6097, please relay to the signees of the petition that their concerns are unfounded.

A Digital ID is simply an online method of confirming your ID that does not require physical documents once it's set up. It works by verifying your existing ID documents such as a passport or driver license against the official record held by government.

The purpose of a Digital ID is to reduce the amount of information that businesses and government need to hold that can be at risk of data theft. By using a Digital ID, people can avoid repeatedly sharing copies of their ID documents and all the information they hold.
The Digital ID Act 2024 puts in place strong privacy and security safeguards to protect individuals who choose to create and use a Digital ID with an accredited Digital ID provider.
The Digital ID Act 2024 ensures that the choice to create and use a Digital ID to access Commonwealth government services is voluntary for individuals.
We thank the signees for their engagement with Digital ID and hope this information provides assurance. You can also find out more at www.digitallDsystem.gov.au.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Finance, Ms Gallagher
Gender and Sexual Orientation
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 3 June 2024 in relation to petition EN6101. This petition appears to be based on misinformation circulating in social media that asserts the United Nations (UN) is seeking to expose young children to sexually explicit material.

The World Health Organization (WHO) and other UN specialised agencies issue technical guidance, norms and standards to support Member States to effectively address health issues, including sexual and reproductive health and rights. Australia is supportive of the UN's work to advance universal access to quality, accurate, and comprehensive sexuality education, consistent with our commitment to human rights and achieving the Sustainable Development Goals.

UN agencies that develop technical guidance on comprehensive sexuality education are strong advocates for the rights of children, including promoting young people's rights to education, health and wellbeing; and protecting children from violence, coercion and exploitation. UN technical guidance on comprehensive sexuality education is age- and developmentally appropriate, responding to the changing needs and capabilities of the child and the young person as they grow. This technical guidance is not legally binding. Member States may choose to apply it according to their national circumstances.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Medicare
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 3 June 2024 regarding Petition Number EN6102—request to increase the Medicare benefit for psychology sessions to a minimum of 20 sessions per year for individuals.

Under the Better Access initiative eligible people can receive a Medicare benefit for up to ten individual and ten group allied mental health services each calendar year. In 2020, an additional ten individual sessions were temporarily made available in response to the mental health impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic. The additional ten sessions ceased as planned on 31 December 2022.

In August 2021the Department of Health and Aged Care commissioned the University of Melbourne to complete an evaluation of the Better Access initiative, with the evaluation's final report published in December 2022. More information can be found on the department's website at www.health.gov.au by searching 'Evaluation of the Better Access initiative—final report'. While the evaluation recommended reinstating the additional 10 sessions, it also showed the number of new people accessing Better Access reduced while the additional 10 sessions were in effect.

Increasing session numbers as part of a tiered model of treatment carries a high-risk of further entrenching inequities. The evaluation found that providing additional services to existing consumers limited the capacity of providers to offer treatment to new users, with many people from lower socioeconomic backgrounds and regional, rural and remote areas missing out. Since the additional Better Access sessions ceased on 31 December 2022, 44,927 additional people entered the program and used the initial 10 Better Access individual treatment sessions in 2023, compared to 2022 figures.

The Australian Government is committed to a whole-of-system approach to mental health reform. The Government is investing in complementary models to deliver more care more fairly and efficiently to those who need it. In the 2024-25 Budget, the Government has invested $361million in the mental health and suicide prevention system. This investment shifts away from the one-size-fits-all approach and will relieve pressure on the Better Access initiative.

The Government is rolling out a national network of 61 Medicare Mental Health Centres (building on the existing Head to Health services) to provide free community-based services for people with moderate to complex needs. While not intended to provide ongoing care, the number of sessions provided to consumers are not capped. A further $29.9 million over four years from 2024-25 will be provided to strengthen the clinical capacity of centres to safely and appropriately support people with severe and complex needs. This includes through a phased adoption of minimum workforce requirements and free telehealth access to psychologists and psychiatrists as part of a multidisciplinary team.

People can find information on their nearest Medicare Mental Health Centre on the Head to Health website at www.headtohealth.gov.au/head-to-health-services or via free call on 1800 595 212 (between 8:30am and 5:00pm weekdays).

The Government is providing $71.7 million over four years from 2024-25 to Primary Health Networks to design and deliver multidisciplinary care for people with severe or complex needs in general practices and other primary care settings. Multidisciplinary teams of social workers, counsellors, peer workers and other mental health workers will provide free wraparound support to patients.

The Government will also update guidance to better support people with chronic mental health conditions and complex needs who are accessing clinical treatment through Better Access to access additional multidisciplinary care through Medicare Benefits Schedule Chronic Disease Management items. Under a Chronic Disease Management Plan, patients can access five sessions delivered by a broader range of allied health professionals including dieticians, exercise physiologists and mental health nurses.

The new National Early Intervention Service will complement Better Access and improve the availability of services at all levels of the stepped care continuum. Lower intensity services can form part of a broader treatment package for people with higher level needs and assist GPs to manage patients with higher level mental health needs in between or while waiting for clinical treatment, specialist care, or where people are reluctant to access higher intensity services.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
International Relations: Australia and Israel
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email referring petition number EN6105, regarding the Ambassador of Israel.
I know the conflict in the Middle East is deeply distressing for many Australians, including the many Australians with a connection to the region and loved ones directly impacted.
The widespread human suffering we are witnessing in Gaza is completely unacceptable. This cannot continue. This war must end.

While Australia is not a central player, we have a respected voice and we are using it to advocate for a ceasefire, the protection of civilians, increased humanitarian assistance and the release of hostages.

Australia continues to support the international community's response to the humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza. Since October, Australia has committed $72.5 million to address urgent needs arising from the conflict in Gaza and the protracted refugee crisis in the region. This includes our commitment in June this year of an additional $10 million through the World Food Programme to provide life-saving food assistance to civilians in Gaza at risk of famine. This is in addition to Australia's annual core funding of $20.6 million for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency.

We are using our voice and our vote in international institutions and forums. In December, Australia voted with 152 countries for a ceasefire at the United Nations, and we support the ceasefire proposal endorsed by the UN Security Council in June this year. We want to see it fully implemented by both parties. Any delay will only see more lives lost.

I have also pressed for a ceasefire, protection of civilians, humanitarian aid and the release of hostages through persistent and extensive engagement with foreign counterparts, including during my visit to the Middle East, as well as with partners in Europe, Canada, Japan, the UK, the US and in our region.

I have pressed the Netanyahu Government directly, as have Government officials in Canberra and in Israel. We continue to make clear Australia's objection to Israel's operation in Rafah and our expectation that Israel act in accordance with international humanitarian law. We have been clear with Israel that it must comply with the binding orders of the International Court of Justice, including to enable the provision of basic services and humanitarian assistance at scale. The Australian Government is denying anyone identified as an extremist settler a visa to travel to Australia.

We are pressing countries with influence over Hamas, to help secure the immediate and unconditional release of remaining hostages. We remain unequivocal in our condemnation of Hamas's horrific terror attacks of 7 October 2023.

We have adopted the most supportive position on recognition of any Australian government in history. We support recognition of a Palestinian state as a part of a peace process. And we are taking actions to make that possible. We want the legitimate aspirations of Palestinians to be realised—because a two-state solution is necessary for a just and enduring peace.

In May, Australia supported expanded Palestinian rights to participate in UN forums and the General Assembly's aspiration for eventual Palestinian membership of the United Nations, consistent with a two-state solution. Alongside key partners, we are looking at how we can support reform of the Palestinian Authority so that it can deliver on the needs of the Palestinian people.

Australia has a long-standing relationship with Israel. Australia maintains diplomatic relations with many countries because it is in our national interests to do so, even where we do not agree with everything those countries do. More than 160 countries maintain diplomatic relations with Israel, enabling advocacy for a just and enduring peace.

This devastating crisis demonstrates the need for a political solution to the long running Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Australia remains steadfast in our support for a two-state solution—a Palestinian state and the State of Israel, living side by side in peace and security within internationally recognised borders.
I appreciate you taking the time to write to me. Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Middle East
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for referring petition number EN6106 regarding the ongoing Hamas-Israel conflict and related matters.
The widespread human suffering we are witnessing in Gaza is completely unacceptable. This cannot continue. This war must end.

While Australia is not a central player to the conflict, we have a respected voice and we are using it to advocate for a ceasefire, the protection of civilians, increased humanitarian assistance and the release of hostages.

Australia continues to support the international community's response to the humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza. Since October, Australia has committed $72.5 million to address urgent needs arising from the conflict in Gaza and the protracted refugee crisis in the region. This includes our commitment in June this year of $10 million through the World Food Programme to help provide life-saving food assistance to civilians in Gaza at risk of famine. Australia also provides annual core funding of $20.6 million for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency.

We are using our voice and our vote in international institutions and forums. In December, Australia voted with 152 countries for a ceasefire at the United Nations, and we support the ceasefire proposal endorsed by the UN Security Council in June this year. We want to see it fully implemented by both parties. Any delay will only see more lives lost.

I have pressed for a ceasefire, protection of civilians, humanitarian aid and the release of hostages through persistent and extensive engagement with foreign counterparts, including during my visit to the Middle East, as well as with partners in Europe, Canada, Japan, the UK, the US and in our region.

I have pressed the Netanyahu Government directly, as have Government officials in Canberra and in Israel. We continue to make clear Australia's objection to Israel's operation in Rafah and our expectation that Israel act in accordance with international humanitarian law.

We are pressing countries with influence over Hamas, to help secure the immediate and unconditional release of remaining hostages. We remain unequivocal in our condemnation of Hamas's horrific terror attacks of 7 October 2023.

Australia has also made clear that we respect the independence of the International Court of Justice (ICJ) and the critical role it plays in upholding international law and the rules¬ based order. We have been clear with Israel that it must comply with the binding orders of the International Court of Justice, including to enable the provision of basic services and humanitarian assistance at scale.

We have adopted the most supportive position on recognition of any Australian government in history. Labor will recognise Palestine—we will do this when our act of recognition meaningfully contributes to a peace process. The grave situation that Palestinians face needs more than symbolism -Australia is working with other countries to make statehood a reality. The only way to achieve a lasting peace is a two-state solution.

In May, Australia supported expanded Palestinian rights to participate in UN forums and the General Assembly's aspiration for eventual Palestinian membership of the United Nations, consistent with a two-state solution. Alongside key partners, we are looking at how we can support reform of the Palestinian Authority so that it can deliver on the needs of the Palestinian people.

The Albanese Government has strengthened Australia's opposition to Israeli settlements by affirming they are illegal under international law and a significant obstacle to peace. We remain deeply concerned by settler violence against Palestinians, which only serves to inflame tensions and undermine stability at this delicate time. The Australian Government will deny anyone identified as an extremist settler a visa to travel to Australia.

Australia has a long-standing relationship with Israel. Australia maintains diplomatic relations with many countries because it is in our national interests to do so, even where we do not agree with everything those countries do. More than 160 countries maintain diplomatic relations with Israel, enabling advocacy for a just and enduring peace.

The Australian Government does not provide financial or military aid to Israel, either directly or indirectly via other countries. Australia has also not supplied weapons or ammunition to Israel since the conflict began and for at least the past five years.

The Australian Government has a contract with Hanwha Defence Australia, not Elbit Systems. The Australian Government contracted Hanwha Defence Australia in December 2023 to deliver and support infantry fighting vehicles for the Australian Army. Hanwha subsequently awarded a contract to Elbit Systems to manufacture the turret for the Australian infantry fighting vehicles. The Australian Government has no direct relationship with Elbit with respect to this contract. It was a commercial decision made by Hanwha and reflects a commercial relationship between Hanwha and Elbit. The components manufactured under this contract are solely for Australian needs, not for export elsewhere.

This devastating crisis demonstrates the need for a political solution to the long running Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Israelis and Palestinians want and deserve to live their lives in peace, security and dignity.
Australia remains steadfast in our support for a two-state solution—a Palestinian state and the State of Israel, living side by side in peace and security within internationally recognised borders.
I trust this information will be of assistance to the petitioners.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Personal Information and Privacy
Dear Chair
In response to petition number EN6115, please relay to the signees of the petition that their concerns are unfounded.

A Digital ID is simply an online method of confirming your ID that does not require physical documents once it's set up. It works by verifying your existing ID documents such as a passport or driver license against the official record held by government.

The purpose of a Digital ID is to reduce the amount of information that businesses and government need to hold that can be at risk of data theft. By using a Digital ID, people can avoid repeatedly sharing copies of their ID documents and all the information they hold. Your information can only be shared with the service you're accessing and only with your consent. When using a Digital ID, the information that is shared when you give consent is typically your name, date of birth and email address.

The Digital ID Act 2024 (the Digital ID Act) puts in place strong privacy and security safeguards to protect individuals who choose to create and use a Digital ID from an accredited Digital ID provider. Accredited providers can only create a Digital ID with an individual's consent and must deactivate an individual's Digital ID if requested to do so.

The Digital ID Act prohibits data profiling to track online behaviour. This and other privacy safeguards are enforceable through civil penalties under the Act. The Digital ID Act also ensures that the choice to create and use a Digital ID to access Commonwealth Government services is voluntary for individuals acting in a personal capacity.
We thank the signees for their engagement with Digital ID and hope this information provides assurance. You can also find out more at www.digitallDsystem.gov.au.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Finance, Ms Gallagher
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 3 June 2024 enclosing Petition EN6119, with 426 signatures, concerning—Pause Immigration to Give Australia a Breather. I appreciate the opportunity to provide a response to the Committee.

The Government released the Migration Strategy (the Strategy) in December last year with a focus on bringing migration back to sustainable levels, while ensuring we get workers with the skills we need into the right places. The Strategy included a range of measures that are expected to halve Net Overseas Migration (NOM) by this financial year. _The Strategy aims to strengthen the integrity and quality of international education and includes policies such as higher English language and financial capacity requirements for international students, as well as measures to address education providers who seek to exploit the visa system. This Strategy is working, with visa grants for international students down by nearly 40% this year compared to last year's levels.

The Government is also working to address housing shortages through significant investment in the Homes for Australia Plan, which aims to build 1.2 million new homes from 1 July 2024. Further information can be found on the Treasury Department's website at:
https://ministers.treasury.gov.au/ministers/julie-collins-2022/media-releases/homes-australia-plan-delivering-more-homes-australians.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6119 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neill

subdebateinfo.title: E-Cigarettes and Vaping Products: Medicinal Cannabis

p.span: E-Cigarettes and Vaping Products: Medicinal Cannabis
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 3 June 2024 regarding petition number EN6127 relating to the accessibility of reusable cannabis vaping devices. I understand that the petition requests reusable cannabis vaping devices to be made accessible to consumers outside pharmacy settings.

The Australian Government has secured passage of new laws for the regulation of vapes, which commenced on 1 July 2024. The new laws address the increasing health risks posed by vaping, particularly to youth and young adults, while at the same time preserving legitimate patient access to therapeutic vapes where clinically appropriate. They are necessary to promote the safe use of all vaping goods in Australia, including those for the administration of medicinal cannabis.

Only vaping devices that have been notified to the Therapeutic Goods Administration under the new arrangements may be lawfully imported into Australia. From 1 July 2024, all vaping goods, including vaping devices for the administration of medicinal cannabis, must be supplied in pharmacy settings.

Vaping devices that may be used for the administration of medicinal cannabis can only be lawfully supplied for use with medicinal cannabis that has been prescribed by a medical practitioner for therapeutic purposes under the special access and authorised prescriber schemes administered by the Therapeutic Goods Administration. It is appropriate that these goods are supplied in pharmacy settings given the nature of the vaping substance and the mode of administration.

By limiting the supply of all vaping devices to pharmacy settings, patients who require vaping devices for legitimate therapeutic purposes can confidently purchase those devices from a pharmacist and receive information about their safe use. Limiting supply of vaping devices to pharmacy settings also assists in identifying and disrupting illicit supply of vapes by retailers.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Visa Refusal or Cancellation
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 3 June 2024 enclosing Petition EN6138, with 237 signatures, concerning the cancellation of visas of people who fail the character test.
The Australian Government is committed to protecting the Australian community.
The decision whether to refuse or cancel the visa of a non-citizen who commits serious crimes or otherwise fails the character test is carefully considered, based on each individual's circumstances.
The Government's policy though is clear, and the protection of the Australian community from harm the key priority.
Where a person's visa is refused or cancelled, they are expected to leave Australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6138 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Gaza
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for referring petition EN6141 regarding sanctions on Israel.
I know the conflict in the Middle East is deeply distressing for many Australians, including the many Australians with a connection to the region and loved ones directly impacted.
The widespread human suffering we are witnessing in Gaza is completely unacceptable. This cannot continue. This war must end.

While Australia is not a central player to the conflict, we have a respected voice and we are using it to advocate for a ceasefire, the protection of civilians, increased humanitarian assistance and the release of hostages.

Australia continues to support the international community's response to the humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza. Since October, Australia has committed $72.5 million to address urgent needs arising from the conflict in Gaza and the protracted refugee crisis in the region. This includes our commitment in June this year of $10 million through the World Food Programme to help provide life-saving food assistance to civilians in Gaza at risk of famine. Australia also provides annual core funding of $20.6 million for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency.

We are using our voice and our vote in international institutions and forums. In December, Australia voted with 152 countries for a ceasefire at the United Nations, and we support the ceasefire proposal endorsed by the UN Security Council in June this year. We want to see it fully implemented by both parties. Any delay will only see more lives lost.

I have pressed for a ceasefire, protection of civilians, humanitarian aid and the release of hostages through persistent and extensive engagement with foreign counterparts, including during my visit to the Middle East, as well as with partners in Europe, Canada, Japan, the UK, the US and in our region.

I have pressed the Netanyahu Government directly, as have Government officials in Canberra and in Israel. We continue to make clear Australia's objection to Israel's operation in Rafah and our expectation that Israel act in accordance with international humanitarian law. We have been clear with Israel that it must comply with the binding orders of the International Court of Justice, including to enable the provision of basic services and humanitarian assistance at scale. The Australian Government is denying anyone identified as an extremist settler a visa to travel to Australia.

We are pressing countries with influence over Hamas, to help secure the immediate and unconditional release of remaining hostages. We remain unequivocal in our condemnation of Hamas's horrific terror attacks of 7 October 2023.

We have adopted the most supportive position on recognition of any Australian government in history. Labor will recognise Palestine—we will do this when our act of recognition meaningfully contributes to a peace process. The grave situation that Palestinians face needs more than symbolism -Australia is working with other countries to make statehood a reality. The only way to achieve a lasting peace is a two-state solution.

In May, Australia supported expanded Palestinian rights to participate in UN forums and the General Assembly's aspiration for eventual Palestinian membership of the United Nations, consistent with a two-state solution. Alongside key partners, we are looking at how we can support reform of the Palestinian Authority so that it can deliver on the needs of the Palestinian people.

Consistent with longstanding practice, the Government does not speculate publicly on whether sanctions will be applied. In pressing for change, we have to consider the full range of tools we have available—diplomacy and dialogue, working in coalitions, multilateral forums, and public statements. Sanctions are not our only choice in responding to a situation of international concern, and they will rarely be our first choice.
This devastating crisis demonstrates the need for a political solution to the long running Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
Australia remains steadfast in our support for a two-state solution—a Palestinian state and the State of Israel, living side by side in peace and security within internationally recognised borders.
I trust this information is of assistance to the petitioners.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Freedom of Speech
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email of 24 June 2024 regarding Petition EN6152—Request to repeal the Online Safety Act 2021.

The Australian Government is committed to protecting and promoting the rights and freedoms of Australians, including freedom of speech and expression. The Government also believes that all people are entitled to respect, equality, dignity, and to be free from hatred and harassment, which undermines Australian values such as freedom of expression and inclusiveness. These principles apply to the measures we take to provide safeguards and protections in the physical environments where Australians live, work and play, and they apply equally to the online environments where Australians engage.

The benefits and harms of engaging in a physical space, compared to online, may manifest differently. However, it is the Government's responsibility to ensure that our democratic norms and values are upheld in both contexts.

The Online Safety Act 2021 (the Act) supp01is Australians online by providing the eSafety Commissioner (the Commissioner) with powers to crack down on cyberbullying, online abuse, illegal and harmful content and the non-consensual sharing of intimate images. It does this through:
a cyberbullying scheme that allows the removal of material from the full range of online services where children are now spending time;
a cyber abuse scheme for adults that assists victims of seriously harmful online abuse to have the material removed;
an image-based abuse scheme to enable removal of non-consensually shared intimate images within 24 hours;
an online content scheme enabling the removal of content that would be refused classification no matter where it is hosted; and
providing the eSafety Commissioner with emergency website blocking powers, for use in an online crisis event.

These powers enable the Commissioner to protect Australians online, while recognising and balancing freedom of speech and expression. In particular, the definition of adult cyber abuse in the Act has a high threshold.

It is only when material crosses a threshold well beyond reasonable commentary or expression of opinion and into the realm of intentional, serious harm and being menacing, harassing or offensive that the Act provides a mechanism for material to be removed.

There will always be a need to balance the rights of individuals online, as there are in other environments, settings and communities. The powers of the Act provide the Commissioner with a reasonable and proportionate means of improving and promoting online safety for Australians.

The Act provides mechanisms to seek the review of removal notice decisions, and is limited 'to the extent (if any) that it would infringe any constitutional doctrine of implied freedom of communication' (section 233). The Government has also brought forward an independent statutory review of operation of the Act, which is being led by Ms Delia Rickard PSM. The Terms of Reference for the review are available at www.infrastructure.gov.au/department/media/publications/terms-reference-statutory-review¬ online-safety-act-2021. I am expecting to receive a final report of the review by 31 October 2024.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Freedom of Speech
Dear Chair
Thank you for contacting me in relation to petition number EN6169, presented to the House of Representatives on 24 June 2024.
The petition calls for the House to enshrine the freedom of speech and freedom of the press in the Australian Constitution.

While the Australian Constitution does not contain any express rights to 'freedom of speech' or 'freedom of the press', the High Court has recognised an implied constitutional freedom of communication on government and political matters. This constitutional protection is essential to the proper functioning of Australia's system of democratic and representative government.

The implied freedom of political communication can be limited only by laws which are proportionate to achieve a legitimate purpose, such as the protection of the community from dangers provoked by material promoting violence. The freedom of political communication is a fundamental human right enjoyed by all Australians, and all people who are in Australia. However, this right is subject to limitations that are reasonable and necessary in a free and democratic society to achieve an appropriate balance between freedom of expression and the protection of groups and individuals from offensive or harmful behaviour.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Occupied Palestinian Territories
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for referring petition EN6173 regarding recognition of a Palestinian State.
The widespread human suffering we are witnessing in Gaza is completely unacceptable. This cannot continue. This war must end.

While Australia is not a central player to the conflict, we have a respected voice and we are using it to advocate for a ceasefire, the protection of civilians, increased humanitarian assistance and the release of hostages.

Australia continues to support the international community's response to the humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza. Since October, Australia has committed $72.5 million to address urgent needs arising from the conflict in Gaza and the protracted refugee crisis in the region. This includes our commitment in June this year of $10 million through the World Food Programme to help provide life-saving food assistance to civilians in Gaza at risk of famine. Australia also provides annual core funding of $20.6 million for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency.

We are using our voice and our vote in international institutions and forums. In December, Australia voted with 152 countries for a ceasefire at the United Nations, and we support the ceasefire proposal endorsed by the UN Security Council in June this year. We want to see it fully implemented by both parties. Any delay will only see more lives lost.

I have pressed for a ceasefire, protection of civilians, humanitarian aid and the release of hostages through persistent and extensive engagement with foreign counterparts, including during my visit to the Middle East, as well as with partners in Europe, Canada, Japan, the UK, the US and in our region.

I have pressed the Netanyahu Government directly, as have Government officials in Canberra and in Israel. We continue to make clear Australia's objection to Israel's operation in Rafah and our expectation that Israel act in accordance with international humanitarian law. We have been clear with Israel that it must comply with the binding orders of the International Court of Justice, including to enable the provision of basic services and humanitarian assistance at scale. The Australian Government is denying anyone identified as an extremist settler a visa to travel to Australia.

We are pressing countries with influence over Hamas, to help secure the immediate and unconditional release of remaining hostages. We remain unequivocal in our condemnation of Hamas's horrific terror attacks of 7 October 2023.

We have adopted the most supportive position on recognition of any Australian government in history. Labor will recognise Palestine -we will do this when our act of recognition meaningfully contributes to a peace process. The grave situation that Palestinians face needs more than symbolism—Australia is working with other countries to make statehood a reality. The only way to achieve a lasting peace is a two-state solution.

In May, Australia supported expanded Palestinian rights to participate in UN forums and the General Assembly's aspiration for eventual Palestinian membership of the United Nations, consistent with a two-state solution. Alongside key partners, we are looking at how we can support reform of the Palestinian Authority so that it can deliver on the needs of the Palestinian people.

In support of a two-state solution, the Albanese Government strengthened Australia's opposition to Israeli settlements by affirming they are illegal under international law and a significant obstacle to peace. We remain deeply concerned by settler violence against Palestinians, which only serves to inflame tensions and undermine stability at this delicate time. The Australian Government will deny anyone identified as an extremist settler a visa to travel to Australia.

The Albanese Government also adopted the name of 'Occupied Palestinian Territories', consistent with the approach taken by key partners, including the UK, EU and New Zealand, as well as the United Nations and the broader international community. In addition, our Government reversed the Morrison Government's decision to recognise West Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, reaffirming Australia's longstanding and bipartisan position that Jerusalem is a final status issue to be resolved through negotiations.
This devastating crisis demonstrates the need for a political solution to the long running Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
Australia remains steadfast in our support for a two-state solution—a Palestinian state and the State of Israel, living side by side in peace and security within internationally recognised borders.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
E-Cigarettes and Vaping Products
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 June 2024 regarding petition EN6174 requesting a lift to the ban on the personal importation of vaping products, including nicotine e-liquid, and imposing quantity limits instead.

The Australian Government is taking clear action to reduce smoking and vaping rates through stronger legislation, enforcement, education, and support. Reforms to the regulation of vapes have been implemented progressively over 2024 to address serious harms posed by vaping. This has included amendments to the customs and therapeutic goods frameworks to introduce stronger controls on the importation of vapes. Bans on the importation of disposable single-use vapes commenced on 1 January 2024 and bans on the importation of non-therapeutic vapes commenced on 1 March 2024.

At the same time, the personal importation scheme for therapeutic vapes under therapeutic goods legislation ceased to operate. This was necessary to address the significant abuse of the personal importation scheme in recent years, and otherwise to complement changes made under customs legislation for the lawful importation of therapeutic vapes. The changes mean that individuals can no longer import therapeutic vapes personally. Only businesses with appropriate licences and permits issued by the Office of Drug Control under customs legislation may lawfully import therapeutic vapes.

These measures are necessary to promote the safe use of all vaping goods in Australia. The reforms address the increasing health risks posed by vaping, particularly to youth and young adults, while at the same time preserving the use of therapeutic vapes for smoking cessation or the management of nicotine dependence where clinically appropriate.

The Government has listened to the concerns of persons who vape and has genuinely sought to facilitate legitimate patient access. Therapeutic vapes containing nicotine must continue to be supplied under prescription by medical or nurse practitioners until 1 October 2024.

From that time, therapeutic vapes may be supplied by pharmacists from behind the counter in pharmacies without prescription to persons aged 18 and over, where certain conditions are met, including that the vapes contain a maximum of 20mg/ml of nicotine, and the quantity does not exceed one month's supply at any one time. More information on accessing therapeutic vapes is available at www.tga.gov.au by using the search term 'Vapes: information for patients and consumers'.

The Government continues to ensure that there are sufficient supports available to persons for smoking and vaping cessation. These initiatives complement other actions being taken by the Government in line with the National Tobacco Strategy 2023-2030 to reduce the rates of tobacco and e-cigarette use including stronger regulation of tobacco products under the Public Health (Tobacco and Other Products) Act 2023.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Health Care
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 June 2024 regarding petition EN6178 in which you have requested that the Australian Government liaises with Norgine Pty Ltd to ascertain whether they will consider re-introducing their product Normacol Plus Granules Carton (Normacol Plus) to the Australian market.

I can confirm that Normacol Plus was included in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG) as a registered complementary medicine with indications (health claims) for laxative purposes. In 2021, the pharmaceutical company that produced Normacol Plus, Norgine Pty Ltd, informed the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) that there was a shortage of this product due to a manufacturing issue, and that the issue was expected to be resolved in 2022. Ultimately however, the product was discontinued from the market and cancelled from the ARTG by the company in 2023, with Norgine Pty Ltd noting that they had made a global decision to discontinue the product.

As the cancellation was a decision of the product owner, and not due to a directive by the TGA, there is unfortunately no further action that the TGA can take. The TGA does not have the legal power to compel a company to apply for the inclusion of a product in the ARTG.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler

subdebateinfo.title: Physical and Sexual Harassment and Violence

p.span: Physical and Sexual Harassment and Violence
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 24 June 2024 to the Minister for Social Services, the Hon Amanda Rishworth MP, concerning petition number EN6193 calling for a National Royal Commission into men's violence against women. The Minister has asked me to respond to you on her behalf.

I acknowledge the concerns raised in this petition and thank those who participated for raising their concerns with me and the Australian Government. However, the Government does not intend to request a Royal Commission be established for the reasons outlined below.

span.span: An ambitious national blueprint is in place.

p.span: Women's safety is a national priority. The Albanese Labor Government is providing the focus and national leadership needed to prevent violence and ensure appropriate support is available to people who need it, when they need it.

The National Plan to End Violence against Women and Children 2022-2032 (the National Plan) is a joint Australian, state and territory government document that sets the national policy agenda for addressing violence against women and children in Australia for the next 10 years.

Through the National Plan, the Australian, state and territory governments have collectively committed.to the vision of ending gender-based violence in one generation. The National Plan is supported by the dedicated Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Action Plan 2023- 25, the First Action Plan 2023-2027, Activities Addendum to the First Action Plan, and the Outcomes Framework, setting the roadmap for how we will work to achieve this vision.

span.span: The voices of victim-survivors are at the forefront of our efforts.

p.span: The National Plan was informed by broad consultation over a period of around two years. More than 3,000 individuals were engaged through various consultation methods to inform the development of the National Plan. Voices of victim-survivors were at the centre of the National Plan's development and are an essential and guiding focus in the implementation of the National Plan and underpinning Action Plans.

span.span: A systems-wide approach with a strong commitment to prevention.

p.span: The National Plan's approach to the primary prevention of violence against women in Australia is founded on Australia's world first guides produced by Our Watch under the 2010-2022 National Plan. This includes Change the story (2nd edition): a shared framework for the primary prevention of violence against women and children in Australia.

This primary prevention approach works across the whole population to address the attitudes, practices and power differentials that drive violence against women and their children. You can find more information about Change the story at Ourwatch.org.au.

span.span: Acknowledging children and young people can be victim-survivors in their own right.

p.span: The National Plan recognises children who have experienced or witnessed family and domestic violence as victim-survivors in their own right and identifies the importance of ensuring children can access supports and services that meet their specific safety and recovery needs.

Accordingly, a key priority of the First Action Plan 2023-27 of the National Plan is the development and implementation of age appropriate, culturally safe programs, which have prevention and early intervention focus to address risk factors and help break the cycle of violence, as well as support recovery and healing.

In the 2024-25 budget, the Albanese Labor Government has invested a further $1.1 billion towards ending gender-based violence, bringing the Government's total investment to $3.4 billion under the National Plan. The $3.4 billion investment includes initiatives focused on children and young people. This includes:

$3.6 million for the Helping Children Heal initiative which aims to support children aged 6-12 years who are struggling to reach developmental, social and educational milestones due to family and domestic violence.

$34.8 million for a nation l early intervention trial for young men and adolescent boys aged 12-18 who present with adverse childhood experiences including family and domestic violence, and who are at risk of perpetrating family, domestic or sexual violence.
$2.8 million to review emergency accommodation services and their suitability for children.
$3.5 million for the Healthy Masculinities Trial and Evaluation (Healthy MaTE) grant to trial activities designed to encourage healthy masculinities among school aged boys.
$3.5 million to support Teach Us Consent to develop and distribute social media resources for young people aged 16 years and above about sexual violence and consent.

span.span: Inbuilt adaptability for emerging areas of need.

p.span: The National Plan acknowledges there will be emerging areas of need and emerging forms of violence that will be addressed over the life of the National Plan. New initiatives and activities to respond to emerging areas will be captured in the annual updates to the First Action Plan Activities Addendum.

The Government also acknowledges more needs to be done to improve our understanding of perpetration of family and domestic violence and accelerate efforts to prevent violence against women and children. Through the Budget 2024-25, the Albanese Labor Government has allocated additional resourcing to strengthen prevention efforts including $4.3 million in 2024-25 to Australia's National Research Organisation for Women's Safety (ANROWS) to expand the evidence base on pathways into and out of perpetration of Family, Domestic and Sexual Violence (FDSV). This funding is in addition to ANROWS recent announcement of research projects on "People who use violence" focused on understanding perpetration of violence to inform policy and practice design for prevention and early intervention. •

The governance structure of the National Plan enables us to continue to seek advice to address emerging issues, including from the Domestic, Family and Sexual Violence Commission, which was established to provide national leadership and promote coordination across a range of domestic, family and sexual violence policies and areas of service delivery.

Together with the states and territories, the Government is focused on strengthening and building on actions to prevent violence. Because the Government cannot end violence against women and children alone, we are continuing to consult with a broad range of stakeholders including victim-survivors and sector representatives.
More information about the work of the Australian, state and territory governments to end violence can be found at www.dss.gov.au/ending-violence.
The Minister appreciates you bringing this matter to her attention. I trust the information provided will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the AssistantMinister for Prevention of Family Violence, Ms Elliot
Telecommunications
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 24 June 2024 regarding Petition EN6199—no flights during curfew in South Australia and 5G radiation upgrades. I apologise for the delay in responding.

Managing the impact of aircraft operations is a difficult issue. The Australian Government aims to minimise this impact on the community through airspace design, noise abatement procedures and land use planning. Every effort is made to ensure that Australian airports operate in a manner that is compatible with the expectations of neighbouring communities.

Adelaide Airport has a curfew in place between 11pm and 6am each day. However, having a curfew does not mean that no aircraft will operate during that time. Certain operations are permitted during the curfew, such as air ambulance, emergency medical evacuations and police operations. These operations are vital to the community and are pe1mitted during the curfew under the Adelaide Airport Curfew Act 1995. There is no consideration for further restricting operations during the curfew at Adelaide Airport.
For further information and enquires regarding the upgrade of telecommunication infrastructure as part of the 5G network, we refer you to the Hon Michelle Rowland MP, Minister for Communications.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms King
Tertiary Education: Mandatory Work Placement
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 24 June 2024 regarding Petition EN6207, concerning the new Commonwealth Prac Payment.

As part of the 2024-25 Budget, the Australian Government is establishing a Commonwealth Prac Payment for eligible nursing, midwifery, teaching and social work students doing their mandatory placements.
The new payment is being established in response to the Australian Universities Accord (the Accord).
Placements are an important part of qualifications for a range of professions that ensure graduates have the skills and experience to enter the workforce and translate learned theory into practice.

The Government understands that placements can impact a student's financial wellbeing and appreciates the challenges many students experience with meeting the cost of living while studying and completing mandatory placements.
While recognising other qualifications require mandatory placements, the Accord recommended the Government focus on nursing, care and teaching professions.

The 2023 Employment White Paper also identified those in care and teaching professions as key enablers for the economy and that unpaid placements discourage many students in care and teaching professions from enrolling and completing courses.

This is the first time the Australian Government has provided financial support for mandatory placements. We are starting with students studying nursing, midwifery, teaching and social work due to significant workforce shortages that need to be addressed as a priority.
Almost every Australian will interact with a nurse, midwife or teacher throughout their life, and social workers are critical to the wellbeing of vulnerable people in the Australian community.

The Accord is not a plan for one budget, but a blueprint for the next decade and beyond. Consideration is being given to other recommendations in the Accord, including that the Government work with tertiary education providers, state and territory governments, industry, business and unions to consider further support by employers (public and private) to mitigate the risk of financial hardship and placement poverty for students in other fields.

In addition to the above, the Government increased support available to students through Austudy, ABSTUDY, Youth Allowance and provided access to more Government Rent Assistance as part of the 2023-24 Budget. These payments support Australians of all ages to attend university to pursue their career ambitions.

The Government has also announced reforms to make the Higher Education Loan Program system fairer by reducing the indexation that is applied to student loans. The proposed change to indexation is to apply the lower of the Consumer Price Index or the Wage Price Index, with effect from 1 June 2023.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare
Mental Health
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 June 2024 on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions (Committee) regarding petition EN6209 which seeks mandatory drug and mental health rehabilitation facilities for children.

The Australian Government acknowledges the significant impact that both mental ill-health and addiction are having on young people. I would like to reassure the Committee that the Government is reducing those impacts through targeted prevention and support programs while maintaining a balanced approach between health and justice.

The conditions upon which involuntary treatment can be mandated are the responsibility of state and territory governments and differ between jurisdictions. It is important to note that evidence shows that treatment is most effective when a person is willing and engaged.

The mental health of young people is a national concern, with the prevalence of mental disorders rising by 50% since 2007, which is why young people's wellbeing remains a focus of the Australian Government.

The organisation headspace is a national support service for young people experiencing, or at risk of, mental ill-health. The Australian Government continues to rollout new headspace services across Australia. There are currently 161 headspace services, and this number will grow to 173 by 2025-26.

The Government is also progressing joint initiatives with state and territory governments under the National Mental Health and Suicide Prevention Agreement to strengthen the headspace platform and improve service integration so young people experiencing severe and complex mental ill-health have better access to supports.
In addition, the Government is commissioning a sector-led consortium to co-design fit for- purpose models of care for young people to ensure they receive care appropriate to their needs.

I would like to also assure the Committee that preventing and minimising the harms associated with the use of alcohol and other drugs on individuals, families and communities remains a key priority for the Government. This approach is set out in the Government's National Drug Strategy 2017-2026 which is available on the Department of Health and Aged Care's website at www.health.gov.au/resources/publications/national-drug-strategy-2017-2026. The Strategy outlines a national commitment to harm minimisation through a balanced adoption of harm reduction strategies. Implementation of the National Drug Strategy is a shared responsibility of all Australian federal, state and territory governments.

The Australian Government is aware that young people face specific risks in relation to alcohol and other drug use. The Government has invested in education and prevention programs in secondary schools, sports clubs, online and in the community to raise awareness with young people about the dangers of drug use and risky drinking. The Government has also provided funding for numerous treatment options for young people experiencing addiction. The department provides a list of organisations, websites and services that offer drug support, counselling and information about drugs and alcohol, and this is available at www.health.gov.au/topics/drugs/drugs-contacts.

In addition, the Australian Government provides significant funding through Primary Health Networks (PHNs) to commission drug and alcohol treatment services nationally. PHNs are independent, not-for-profit, regionally based organisations who commission health services to meet the health care needs of their communities at a local level. More information on PHN commissioned services can be found on the department's website at www.health.gov.au/our-work/phn/your-local-PHN.

The Australian Government will continue to work with PHNs, state and territory governments and the Mental Health and Alcohol and Other Drug sectors, to assist young people to access the support they need.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the AssistantMinister for Mental Health and Suicide Prevention, Ms McBride
Covid-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 24 June 2024 regarding petition EN6210—vaccination mandates and Vaccine-induced Immune Thrombotic Thrombocytopenia.

The Australian Government strongly supports immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to reduce the impact of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

In 2023, AstraZeneca made a decision to formally discontinue their COVID-19 vaccine, Vaxzevria, in Australia. As expected, first generation vaccines were superseded by newer vaccines targeting the strains of the virus now circulating. Australia's pandemic supply stock of Vaxzevria expired on 21 March 2023.

Vaxzevria remained provisionally approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG) until 23 April 2024 when AstraZeneca voluntarily cancelled Vaxzevria from the ARTG. This was a decision of the company, due to no current or anticipated future demand of the vaccine and follows similar business decisions made overseas.

As the petition notes, in May 2024 AstraZeneca announced that it has initiated the worldwide withdrawal of its COVID-19 vaccine. This was not a decision based on safety, rather, the company has advised this was due to a surplus of available updated vaccines since the pandemic leading to a decline in demand for its vaccine.

I can assure you the safety of the Australian population has always been the Government's highest priority. For this reason, decisions regarding COVID-19 vaccines have been, and continue to be, based on the expert advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI) and the TGA. The Department of Health and Aged Care acknowledges publicly available information regarding the safety of the AstraZeneca vaccine and links with a rare but serious side effect called thromboses with thrombocytopenia syndrome (TTS).

The TGA and ATAGI closely monitored the emergence of TTS, meeting regularly to consider the emergence of evidence both locally and internationally in the context of the epidemiology of the COVID-19 pandemic at the time and consulting with the department, the TGA and relevant specialists.

ATAGI published several statements in line with the evolving safety situation, including information for consumers and clinicians on the significance of this condition and to be alert for the symptoms and signs of thromboses.

A range of severity of illness was reported in Australia. Some cases were relatively mild, some had significant morbidity, and some were fatal. TTS was very rare. In Australia, the last case of TTS reported by the TGA was in December 202l1. At that time, the rates of TTS were estimated to be:
about 2 per 100,000 people vaccinated with AstraZeneca aged 60 years or older
about 2 to 3 per 100,000 people vaccinated with AstraZeneca under 60 years of age.

The overall case fatality rate in Australia was lower than reported internationally. This was likely due to increased detection due to increased awareness, as well as early diagnosis and treatment. The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in significant challenges for people across Australia, and the Government recognises the difficulties posed for communities during this time.

While the Government encourages as many Australians to be vaccinated as possible, the Government's position is that vaccination is voluntary. The Government is not responsible for any vaccine mandates. State and territory public health orders may set mandatory vaccination requirements for certain professions and the limited exemptions that apply.

In the absence of public health orders setting vaccine mandates in the workplace, the way in which the risk of COVID-19 in the workplace is managed becomes a matter for each individual workplace to determine. Organisations are responsible for ensuring their health and safety policies are current and comply with all relevant legislative requirements.

State and territory governments have primary operational responsibility for emergency management and public health within their respective jurisdictions. This responsibility extends to mandating vaccines for specific cohorts of workers in specific settings.

State and territory governments can review their public health orders and vaccination requirements at any time without input from the Commonwealth. The Government cannot intervene or override state and territory mandates.
